<br>

            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671506-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">These limitations are additional to any imposed by the conditions of engagement and are a consequence of both the building and the inspection circumstances. These limitations are, therefore, additional items that are drawn to the attention of the client. Other constraints may include but are not limited to floor coverings, furniture, stored goods, inaccessible areas, and exceptional limitations (e.g. snow, parked vehicles, building works, dogs, etc.). The surveyor cannot comment on covered, concealed or otherwise readily visible areas.<br>
<br>
There may be signs of hidden defects, in which case recommendations are made for further investigation. Without such evidence, The surveyor will assume that such areas are free from defects in producing this report. If assurance is required on these matters, it will be necessary to carry out exposure works. Unless these are done before the exchange of contracts, there is a risk that additional defects and consequential repair costs will be incurred if discovered later.<br>
<br>
Each room has been inspected in detail. Random moisture meter readings have been taken where possible. Fitted floor coverings have not been lifted unless reasonably practicable.<br>
<br>
The visual inspection of the services is to the visible areas only. Therefore, no comments are made about the soundness of any part of the property or services that are not visible. You must appreciate that some service pipes and cables are covered, and access panels cannot be opened without disturbing decorations.<br>
<br>
This is not an invasive survey. Also, some service pipework is below flooring, making inspection impossible without exposure. In such circumstances, discovering leakages and rot, if any, may not be possible.<br>
<br>
The building services, such as electrical installation and heating, have not been officially tested. Therefore, appropriate advice has been given to having the services inspected by an approved contractor.<br>
<br>
No beams, lintels or other supporting components were exposed to allow examination. Therefore, it has not been possible to comment fully upon the condition of these concealed areas. Therefore, you must accept the risk of unseen defects should you wish to proceed without further investigation.<br>
<br>
It should be appreciated that parts of the property may be old. Accordingly, such areas of the structure and fabric should not be expected to be as new. You must give due regard to natural deterioration due to the elements and usage.<br>
<br>
Restoration to a condition 'as new', particularly brickwork, stonework, ironwork, joinery, and roofing materials, can prove uneconomic.<br>
<br>
This report reflects on the condition of the various parts of the property at the survey time. It is possible that defects could arise between the survey date and the date upon which you take occupation. It must be accepted that this report can only comment on what is visible and reasonably accessible to the surveyor at the time.</div>

        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671517-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property is being offered for sale on a leasehold basis, with vacant possession being provided upon completion. It would be best if you asked your Legal Advisor to confirm this point. The property was occupied at the time of inspection.<br>
<br>
A leasehold property is a type of real estate property in which a person or entity owns the right to use and occupy the property for a specified period, subject to the terms of a lease or tenancy agreement with the freehold owner.<br>
<br>
In other words, the leaseholder has the right to use and occupy the property for the duration of the lease, which can be for years or decades, depending on the terms of the lease agreement. However, the leaseholder does not own the property itself, as the freehold owner retains ownership of the property and has certain rights to it, such as the ability to impose restrictions on the use of the property or to charge rent.<br>
<br>
Leasehold properties are most commonly associated with apartments or flats, but they can also apply to other types of properties, such as commercial buildings or land. The lease agreement terms can vary widely and include provisions for rent increases, maintenance responsibilities, and other conditions. At the end of the lease term, the property reverts to the freehold owner unless the lease is renewed or extended.<br>
<br>
IMPORTANT NOTE<br>
It is important to note that as a leasehold property, the freeholder will likely maintain the block's common areas, such as the roofs, walls, and grounds. Your Legal Advisor should check if any planned maintenance works are due for these areas.<br>
<br>
Planned maintenance may include repairs, renovations, or improvements to the block's common areas. It is important to be aware of any upcoming maintenance works, as they may impact the property's use and result in additional costs for leaseholders.<br>
<br>
A sinking fund is a reserve of money set aside to cover the cost of future maintenance or repairs to the property. Ensuring that the sinking fund is adequately funded to cover upcoming works is important. Your legal Advisor should also check if a sinking fund is in place to cover the cost of any planned maintenance works.<br>
<br>
Checking for planned maintenance works and the availability of a sinking fund can help you make an informed decision about purchasing the property and ensure that you are aware of any potential costs or disruptions to its use.</div>

Council tax rates may increase annually. In England and Scotland, valuation bands are based on the value of a property on 1 April 1991, not what it is worth today. In Wales, valuation bands are based on the value of a property on 1 April 2003.<br>

If you decide to proceed with purchasing this property, you may wish to appeal against the band. A Land Registry search may reveal the cost of the property in April 1991.<br>

 <br>
According to the council's geographic information system, the property is located within a conservation area. An Article 4 Direction Order is a blanket restriction on permitted development over the area within or close to a conservation area. It does not mean that you are not allowed to carry out work. However, you must obtain permission from the local authority to undertake any work on the building's external fabric. Your Legal Advisor should confirm this point.<br>
<br>
Below is an example of the work which will require planning approval:<br>
<br>
‚Ä¢ the enlargement, improvement or other alteration of a dwelling house, including changes to windows, front doors, railings and other metalwork, plasterwork, doorcases or the like<br>
‚Ä¢ the painting of the exterior of any building<br>
‚Ä¢ the erection, construction, maintenance, improvement or alteration of a gate, fence, wall or other means of enclosure<br>
‚Ä¢ the enlargement of a dwelling house consisting of an addition or alteration to its roof, including the alteration or removal of chimneys and chimney pots<br>
‚Ä¢ the erection or construction of a porch outside any external door of a dwelling house<br>
‚Ä¢ the provision within the curtilage of a dwelling house of a hard surface for any purpose incidental to the enjoyment of the dwelling house as such<br>
‚Ä¢ the installation, alteration or replacement of a satellite antenna on a dwelling house or within the curtilage of a dwelling house.</div>

        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671523-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">A survey has been undertaken to ensure the structure is in a condition whereby you will not suffer unexpected financial losses in the future, and significant defects identified during the inspection are included in the report.<br>
<br>
In the surveyor's opinion, the structure was in adequate condition; however, some defects require repair. The surveyor's opinion has been provided at the end of each section, indicating whether the condition or defect would warrant a revision of your offer. This opinion assumes you are aware that the property requires work in the visible areas. However, if you were not previously aware of these issues, you may wish to revise your offer regardless of the surveyor's opinion.<br>
<br>
The surveyor cannot provide you with an answer as to whether you should proceed with the purchase. Still, it is strongly recommended that you consider whether you can afford the time and cost to bring this property up to a proper standard where defects or design flaws are identified. You are advised to obtain quotes from contractors for a specific figure. In my opinion, you have the following options:<br>
<br>
1. You should ensure that the defects noted in this report are remedied before purchasing the property, but the Vendor would unlikely undertake all of the work.<br>
<br>
2. You may wish to submit a revised offer to the Vendor considering the findings in this report, which is the more common option than option one. You may wish to revise your offer based on the survey findings. It is often asked what sums would be worth putting forward to the vendors to consider a revised offer. You can revise your offer to whatever you want, but the Vendor is not obligated to accept any revised offer. However, when revising your offer, you would best use the items you would not be reasonably expected to know about as a layperson, such as defective drainage, electrical rewiring and upgrades, dampness, etc. You may use the findings to decide whether to proceed with the purchase, revising your offer with the seller.<br>
<br>
3. Alternatively, considering the defects, you may wish not to proceed with the purchase. <br>
<br>
PRIORITISING THE WORKS<br>
When planning to work on a property, following a logical sequence of steps is important to ensure the work is completed efficiently and effectively. The following order of work is typically recommended and should be used where applicable:<br>
<br>
1. Roofing: The first step is to ensure the roof is in good condition. Any repairs or replacements to the roof should be carried out before any other works are started. This will prevent any damage to the internal structure of the property.<br>
<br>
2. Extension: If you plan to extend the property, the next step is to obtain the necessary planning permission from the local authority. Once permission has been granted, the extension should be built before any internal works are started.<br>
<br>
3. Structural works: If any structural works are required, such as removing load-bearing walls, these should be carried out before any internal decorations are started.<br>
<br>
4. Plumbing and electrical works: Once the structural works are completed, the next step is to carry out any necessary plumbing and electrical works. This includes installing new pipes, radiators, lighting, and electrical sockets.<br>
<br>
5. Bathroom and kitchen installation: After the plumbing and electrical works are completed, the bathrooms and kitchen fittings should be installed. This includes cabinets, sinks, toilets, showers, and kitchen appliances.<br>
<br>
6. Plastering: Once the bathroom and kitchen installation is complete, the walls and ceilings should be plastered to create a smooth surface for painting or wallpapering.<br>
<br>
7. Internal decoration: Once the plastering is completed, the walls and ceilings can be decorated with paint or wallpaper. This is also the time to install any flooring, such as carpet or tiles.<br>
<br>
Following this work order ensures that your property is extended and renovated logically and efficiently, minimising the risk of delays or complications. It is important to engage the services of experienced professionals to carry out the work to a high standard and ensure that all necessary regulations and requirements are met.<br>
<br>
If you have any further queries about the report, you must first contact the surveyor at +447901333164 (Whatsapp, SMS) or email info@flettons.com. The surveyor's contact details are in the report submission email.</div>

            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671528-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The breakdown of estimated costs is an additional service and was not requested. Therefore, any reference to the estimated breakdown of costs in the report is not applicable.<br>
<br>
REVISING YOUR OFFER<br>
As the building survey report has identified any unexpected and essential works that need to be carried out, you can use this information to revise your offer with the vendor. Here's how you can do it:<br>
<br>
1. Review the building survey report: You should carefully review the building survey report to understand the essential work needed. These may include repairs, renovations, or upgrades necessary to ensure the safety and integrity of the property.<br>
<br>
2. Get quotes for the works: The client can obtain quotes from reputable contractors for the essential works identified in the survey report. These quotes will help them determine the cost of the works and the impact on the property's overall value. If you find it difficult to obtain quotes, we can provide a breakdown of estimated costs for an additional fee.<br>
<br>
3. Determine the revised offer: Based on the cost of the essential works, you can determine a revised offer that reflects the cost and any additional compensation they may require. This revised offer can be submitted to the vendor or via their agent.<br>
<br>
4. Negotiate with the vendor: The vendor may accept or reject the revised offer, or they may counter with their offer. The client should be prepared to negotiate and work with the vendor to reach a mutually acceptable agreement.<br>
<br>
Our building survey report is a comprehensive report highlighting the essential improvement and provisional works required for the property. It is important to note that the revised offer should only reflect the cost of essential works that were not expected to be known by a layperson. If the works are cosmetic or non-essential, the vendor may not be willing to negotiate on price. <br>
<br>
Essential works are those that are required to maintain the safety and integrity of the property. For example, essential works may include:<br>
<br>
1. Repairing a leaking roof or damaged foundation that could lead to water damage or structural problems<br>
2. Upgrading outdated or unsafe electrical or plumbing systems<br>
3. Fixing a faulty heating or cooling system that could impact the habitability of the property<br>
4. Remediating hazardous materials such as asbestos or lead-based paint<br>
5. Addressing any fire safety issues or ensuring that the property is up to code<br>
<br>
These are just a few examples of essential works that could impact the property's value and its occupants' safety. If the building survey report identifies any of these issues, the client can use this information to revise their offer with the vendor to reflect the cost of the essential works.<br>
<br>
WATCH THE VIDEO GUIDE HERE<br>
https://youtu.be/c4j3oi_LAps</div>

            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671532-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property is a purpose-built flat constructed circa 1900-1930. The construction principles used are typical for a property built in this era. The roof is pitched and finished with a tiled roof covering. The purlins support the rafters, which are then supported by diagonal timbers called struts, which sit on the top of the spine wall in the centre of the building. <br>
 <br>
A property of this type is usually constructed on a concrete foundation. The sub-floor vents to the front and rear elevations indicate that a floating timber floor is in situ. Beneath this suspended timber floor is a concrete sub-floor or oversite. The subfloor vents are in place to allow air to circulate in the subfloor void area. Inadequate ventilation to subfloor voids can result in dry rot to the floor timbers causing substantial damage. <br>
 <br>
Given the property's age, asbestos may be located within this property. Therefore, you are advised to conduct an asbestos survey to check all building areas thoroughly. You must commission an approved asbestos surveyor to undertake a survey and provide you with a report. <br>
 <br>
Although we endeavour to identify asbestos-containing materials, we are not qualified asbestos surveyors and can only presume that certain items may be asbestos-containing materials. If asbestos materials are identified, they will be highlighted in section 11.2.<br>
<br>
For some useful information about the area, check out (The accuracy in the following third-party link cannot be guaranteed): https://checkmypostcode.uk/</div>

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671534-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The main roof is of mansard design, typical of 1930s apartment blocks, and is covered with single-lap concrete tiles. The roof structure is shared across the block and forms part of the communal fabric maintained by the freeholder or management company. The roof surfaces to the front and rear sections were inspected from ground level only, supplemented by binoculars, as the flat central section was not visible during inspection. No safe access was available to view this area, and therefore its condition could not be confirmed.<br>
<br>
The visible tiled slopes appeared in adequate condition overall, with a uniform surface and no significant displacement or distortion of the roof structure. Several slipped or misaligned tiles were noted, particularly to the rear section above the part of the block containing the subject flat. These are minor but should be refixed promptly by a qualified roofing contractor to prevent water ingress during periods of heavy rain.<br>
<br>
Concrete tiles of this type are robust and durable, with an expected service life of 60 to 80 years, but they can become brittle and porous with age. The roof coverings are now well within that typical lifespan range and likely approaching mid-life. Refixing loose tiles and replacing any cracked or damaged units will help extend serviceable life.<br>
<br>
The parapet wall along the front elevation is capped with cast-concrete coping stones that appeared secure and generally in sound condition. However, the drips beneath the coping stones are insufficient, allowing rainwater to run down the wall face, leading to frost-related damage in the upper brickwork. This requires attention as part of external maintenance, with improved drip detailing and localised brick repairs recommended.<br>
<br>
Behind the parapet, a box gutter is assumed to collect rainwater from the junction between the flat and sloping sections. As this could not be seen, its condition is unknown. Box gutters of this age are often lined with bituminous felt or lead and are vulnerable to blockage, corrosion, or water ponding if not regularly cleared. The management company should arrange for an invasive inspection of the box gutter during the next maintenance cycle to confirm its integrity and ensure outlets are free-flowing.<br>
<br>
There was no evidence of significant deflection or sagging in the roof profile, suggesting the structure remains stable. No signs of active leaks or ceiling dampness were reported within the upper flats, indicating that the visible coverings continue to perform adequately.<br>
<br>
Given the age of the building, routine inspection and maintenance of flashings, ridge tiles, and gutters should be carried out annually as part of the freeholder‚Äôs maintenance schedule.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The main roof is in generally adequate condition for its age, with isolated slipped tiles at the rear requiring prompt attention. The flat central section could not be inspected and should be checked during the next maintenance programme to ensure that gutters and flashings remain watertight. The parapet coping drips require improvement to prevent further brickwork saturation. Subject to these minor works and regular roof inspections, the covering should provide a remaining serviceable life of approximately ten years. Failure to maintain the box gutter or replace slipped tiles could lead to water ingress, localised dampness, and costly secondary repairs to ceilings and internal finishes.</div>

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671536-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The building retains several original chimney stacks located along the ridge line, typical of 1930s construction. These are of brick construction built integrally with the concrete frame. The stacks appear stable and upright with no evidence of leaning, bulging, or open joints visible from ground level. The brickwork is aged but remains adequately bonded, and no spalling or loss of mortar was noted in the visible sections.<br>
<br>
Each stack is finished with a cement flaunching at the top, which appeared intact with no visible cracking or detachment. The flaunching provides a weathering seal around the base of the chimney pots and should be inspected routinely to ensure it remains watertight, as deterioration can allow water ingress into the flues.<br>
<br>
The chimney pots are traditional clay types, all of which have been capped or fitted with ventilated cowls, indicating that the flues are now redundant. The cappings are well-seated and effective in preventing rainwater entry and bird nesting. Ventilated caps also allow a small degree of airflow through the disused flues, helping to prevent internal condensation and damp staining. These should remain in place and checked periodically for secure fixing.<br>
<br>
Lead flashings were visible at the junctions between the stacks and roof slopes. These appeared well formed and seated correctly into brickwork joints with no signs of lifting or deterioration from ground level. Given their age, routine re-dressing or re-pointing of the flashings should be carried out within the next five years as part of planned maintenance to maintain watertight integrity.<br>
<br>
No staining or watermarks were noted on internal ceilings or chimney breasts, suggesting the stacks remain weathertight. The combination of stable brickwork, intact flaunching, and effective lead flashings indicates that the chimney structures are performing adequately.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The chimney stacks, pots, and flashings are in adequate condition for their age. All flues are capped, and no signs of instability or leakage were observed. Minor maintenance such as re-dressing of lead flashings and checking of mortar joints and flaunching should be undertaken within five years to preserve weatherproofing. Subject to this routine upkeep, the stacks should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to maintain flashings or flaunching could result in water ingress and damp staining within the upper walls or ceilings.</div>

    <div class="row">

        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671537-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The building has timber fascia boards located behind the rear guttering, forming part of the eaves detail to the mansard roof. These fascias are painted softwood and appear generally sound, though sections show flaking paint and minor weathering consistent with age. The paint failure exposes bare timber, which, if left untreated, may lead to gradual decay. The affected areas should be prepared and repainted with a high-quality exterior microporous paint within the next twelve months to maintain weather protection.<br>
<br>
The soffits at the rear appear to be formed in concrete, integrated into the building‚Äôs structural frame rather than as separate timber components. These surfaces are stable, with no evidence of cracking, spalling, or staining from water penetration.<br>
<br>
There are no visible bargeboards, as the roof construction and parapet walls conceal the roof edges. The existing fascia boards should be periodically maintained, and upgrading to uPVC replacements may be considered during future roof maintenance to reduce ongoing painting requirements.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The existing fascia boards are in adequate condition but require repainting within twelve months to prevent weather damage. The concrete soffits are stable and require no action other than normal cleaning. Subject to these minor works and cyclical redecoration every five to seven years, the eaves components should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to repaint the fascias could allow moisture ingress and early timber decay.</div>

        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671538-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The rainwater goods consist predominantly of uPVC gutters and downpipes fitted to the rear of the building, replacing the original cast-iron system. The uPVC components appeared generally well aligned and free from significant damage, distortion, or leakage. The joints at gutter angles and outlets were intact, with no visible signs of water staining on the adjoining walls to indicate overflow or joint failure.<br>
<br>
At the rear, the gutters discharge into vertical uPVC downpipes that connect into ground-level gullies. The downpipes appeared securely fixed to the wall with sound brackets, and no evidence of blockages or leakage was noted. However, the gullies at the base are worn and require localised repair and re-bedding to maintain a proper watertight seal and ensure that rainwater drains away efficiently.<br>
<br>
The rainwater system at the front of the property could not be fully seen due to the parapet wall concealing the box gutter that runs behind it. This box gutter likely collects rainwater from the mansard roof and channels it towards outlets connected to the downpipes. As box gutters are prone to blockage and corrosion if not regularly maintained, it is recommended that the management company arrange for an invasive inspection during the next maintenance cycle to confirm that the lining and outlets remain watertight and free-flowing.<br>
<br>
Overall, the visible rainwater goods are in adequate condition. Regular maintenance‚Äîparticularly cleaning of gutters and inspection of concealed box gutters‚Äîis essential to prevent overflow and associated damp penetration into the parapet brickwork. The uPVC components have an expected service life of 20 to 25 years, subject to periodic clearing and minor joint maintenance.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The rainwater goods are performing adequately, with the uPVC gutters and downpipes in sound condition. The ground-level gullies require localised repair, and the concealed box gutter behind the front parapet must be inspected during the next maintenance cycle. Routine cleaning should be carried out at least twice a year to prevent blockages. Subject to this upkeep, the system should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to maintain or inspect the box gutter could result in blockages, overflow, and damp penetration into the upper brickwork.</div>

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671539-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The external walls are constructed of traditional 1930s clay facing brickwork, forming the infill between the concrete frame structure of the block. The brickwork generally appears true, plumb, and well bonded, with no evidence of structural movement or bulging. The mortar joints are aged but remain adequately compacted, with only minor localised erosion and weathering visible. Some sections, particularly at the rear, show wear to the pointing that should be repointed as part of routine maintenance within the next five years to maintain weatherproofing.<br>
<br>
At the front elevation, the parapet wall is capped with cast-concrete coping stones that are secure and aligned. However, the drip edges beneath the coping stones are insufficient, allowing rainwater to track down the wall face. This has led to frost-related damage and slight surface erosion to the brickwork immediately below. The affected bricks should be repaired or replaced where spalled, and the coping stones adjusted or refitted with improved drips to prevent further saturation.<br>
<br>
The brickwork at the rear elevation is in slightly better condition, with consistent mortar joints and no significant defects observed. The cement plinth at the base of the wall is intact but exhibits minor cracking near the fire escape steps, which appears to be age-related. These cracks should be sealed during the next maintenance cycle to prevent water penetration and freeze‚Äìthaw damage.<br>
<br>
No evidence of rising damp, penetrating damp, or sulphate attack was seen on the external walls, and all elevations appeared dry. The presence of mature trees near the rear of the block presents a potential long-term risk to wall stability through root pressure or moisture variation, although no visible effects were noted. Tree growth should continue to be monitored by the management company.<br>
<br>
The external brickwork is of a durable type with an expected lifespan well in excess of 80 years if maintained. Regular repointing and repainting of joinery will ensure continued weather resistance.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The external walls are in adequate condition for the property‚Äôs age, with only minor weathering and localised frost damage beneath the parapet coping stones. Repointing of eroded mortar and repair of affected bricks should be carried out within five years. The coping stones require improved drip detailing to prevent further water run-off onto the brickwork. Subject to these minor works and ongoing maintenance, the walls should remain serviceable for 10+ years. Failure to address frost-damaged areas or maintain pointing could lead to progressive water penetration and deterioration of the masonry.</div>

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671540-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The window heads across the building are likely to consist of reinforced concrete lintels integrated into the original 1930s construction. This is typical of concrete-framed apartment blocks of that period, where the external brick panels are supported by in-situ or pre-cast concrete lintels spanning over the window openings. These components distribute the load from the brickwork above each opening to the surrounding wall and provide long-term stability when properly maintained. Concrete lintels of this age typically have a design life of over 80 years, but surface deterioration and corrosion of embedded steel reinforcement can occur when the concrete becomes porous or cracks.<br>
<br>
From ground level inspection, no significant cracking or deflection was visible above the window heads, which indicates that the lintels are continuing to perform adequately. The absence of stepped cracking or bulging of brickwork around openings further supports this conclusion. However, minor staining and weathering were noted to several areas of brickwork below the parapet coping stones, suggesting that occasional water run-off may be penetrating these upper sections. While not directly affecting the lintels at present, long-term exposure to moisture could accelerate carbonation and reinforcement corrosion within the concrete lintels if left unattended.<br>
<br>
The lintels are likely rendered or painted in places and may have been overcoated during past redecorations. Where coatings fail or flake away, small cracks or spalling can occur due to freeze‚Äìthaw action. During the next external maintenance cycle, a close-up inspection should be arranged by a qualified contractor using safe access equipment to confirm that the concrete surfaces remain intact and free from rust staining or cracking. Any exposed reinforcement or spalled concrete must be repaired using a suitable concrete repair mortar and corrosion inhibitor, followed by repainting with a breathable masonry paint.<br>
<br>
Above some of the communal and flat windows, small projecting brick or concrete sills were observed, performing the role of drip mouldings. These appeared largely intact, although minor paint peeling was visible on the associated timber sills beneath. This has no immediate structural impact but should be redecorated within twelve months to prevent moisture penetration into the adjoining masonry and timber components.<br>
<br>
There is no evidence of sagging or settlement around the critical steel-framed windows, suggesting that both the steel frames and their supporting lintels remain secure. However, where steel frames meet the concrete lintel, differential thermal movement over time can open hairline cracks in the render or pointing above the frame. These should be sealed during maintenance to prevent water ingress into the interface between the steel and concrete.<br>
<br>
No evidence was found of historical reinforcement corrosion, which typically presents as rust staining or cracking along the line of embedded steel bars. The absence of such signs indicates that the lintels remain sound. Nonetheless, due to the age of the building and the exposure of the elevations, carbonation of the concrete is likely to have progressed several millimetres inward. Periodic inspection during major external redecorations is recommended to ensure that deterioration does not advance undetected.<br>
<br>
The estimated remaining lifespan of the concrete lintels and window heads is 10+ years, subject to ongoing maintenance and repair of surrounding finishes. These components generally require minimal upkeep apart from sealing small cracks and repainting during cyclical maintenance. Should future refurbishment works involve window replacement, care must be taken not to damage the lintel edges during frame removal, as this can expose reinforcement and initiate corrosion.<br>
<br>
Given the building‚Äôs leasehold status, responsibility for lintel maintenance will rest with the freeholder or management company as part of the overall external fabric. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm that such works are included within the cyclical maintenance plan or sinking fund provision.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The concrete lintels and window heads are performing adequately and show no evidence of distress or structural movement. Localised staining and weathering are superficial and can be managed through redecoration. A high-level inspection should be carried out at the next maintenance cycle to confirm that no reinforcement corrosion or spalling is developing. Subject to this routine maintenance, the lintels are likely to remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to maintain protective coatings or repair minor cracks could allow moisture to reach the reinforcement, leading to corrosion and costly remedial work later. Responsibility for this maintenance lies with the freeholder or management company, and confirmation of future maintenance plans should be obtained by the buyer‚Äôs legal adviser.</div>

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings -->
</nav><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false -->
</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671541-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The windows throughout the block are original 1930s Critall steel-framed units with single glazing. These are typical of the period and contribute to the building‚Äôs architectural character but are thermally inefficient compared with modern double-glazed alternatives. The steel frames generally appear intact and securely fixed within their openings, though surface corrosion was observed to several windows, particularly around the kitchen and bathroom areas where condensation levels are highest. The corrosion is currently superficial but requires cleaning and repainting within the next two years to prevent deterioration.<br>
<br>
Many of the timber window cills beneath the steel frames show signs of paint failure and early-stage decay caused by prolonged condensation and minor water penetration. The affected cills, particularly at the front elevation and around the communal stairwell window, exhibit flaking paint and some softness to the timber surface. Localised repair should be carried out by cutting back decayed sections, treating exposed timber with a preservative hardener, and rebuilding with a two-part epoxy filler before repainting with a microporous external-grade paint. Complete replacement is not yet necessary but may be required in the medium term if decay progresses.<br>
<br>
Externally, the paint coatings to the window frames are aged and uneven, with local flaking and rust spots visible. Repainting using a rust-inhibiting metal primer followed by two coats of exterior-grade enamel paint is recommended within the next redecoration cycle. Regular repainting every five to seven years will help extend the lifespan of the steelwork and prevent corrosion.<br>
<br>
All windows are single-glazed, and draughts are likely to occur in windy conditions. Condensation may also form on the internal glass during colder months due to poor thermal performance. Where replacement is permitted by the freeholder, consideration should be given to upgrading to steel-look double-glazed units with integrated trickle vents to improve energy efficiency and comfort while maintaining the building‚Äôs visual character.<br>
<br>
Operationally, the windows generally open and close, though some were noted to be stiff or difficult to operate due to paint build-up and slight distortion over time. Maintenance such as easing hinges, oiling mechanisms, and freeing paint-sealed joints should be undertaken by a specialist window contractor to restore smooth operation.<br>
<br>
No cracked glazing panes were identified, and the putty lines appeared intact. The window junctions with the surrounding masonry are well sealed, and no active water ingress was evident internally.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The Critall steel-framed windows are in adequate condition for their age, though surface corrosion and paint deterioration require attention within two years. Timber cills show localised decay that should be repaired and repainted to prevent further deterioration. Regular redecoration and lubrication of window mechanisms will extend service life, which is expected to be approximately ten years subject to maintenance. Upgrading to modern double-glazed alternatives could improve energy efficiency and ease of use. Failure to repaint or repair corroded areas may lead to accelerated rusting, timber decay, and potential water ingress.</div>

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671542-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The main entrance doors to the block are timber-framed with Georgian wired glass panels, consistent with the 1930s architectural style. The door frames and pediment surrounds are well constructed and in generally sound condition, showing only minor surface wear. The paintwork is slightly aged and would benefit from redecoration within the next two years to maintain appearance and weather protection. The Georgian wired glass panels are intact and secure, providing both light and a degree of fire resistance typical for communal entrance doors of this period.<br>
<br>
The main communal entrance is fitted with a telephone entry and intercom system that appeared to be operational at the time of inspection. This provides an appropriate level of controlled access to the building and enhances security for residents. The door locks are traditional mortice deadlocks and a surface-mounted rim lock arrangement. Both locks function, although for improved fire safety and ease of egress, the current double-deadlock system should be upgraded to thumb-turn mechanisms. This will allow residents to exit quickly in an emergency without the use of keys.<br>
<br>
The fire exit door leading from the kitchen area of the flat to the rear communal escape route is also of timber construction with a Georgian wired glass panel. The door and frame are serviceable and secure, although the locking arrangement again consists of a rim lock and deadlock. As this door forms part of a designated escape route, it should also be upgraded to a thumb-turn locking system to comply with modern fire safety expectations.<br>
<br>
No evidence of distortion, water ingress, or decay was found to the external doors or frames. Hinges are secure, and all doors fit reasonably well within their frames. The entry door to the flat itself closes with minor frame strike due to hinge wear and the absence of a self-closing mechanism. The addition of a door closer would improve both fire resistance and security.<br>
<br>
Paint finishes on all external door and frame components are serviceable but showing signs of weathering. Repainting with a high-quality exterior-grade system should be completed within the next redecoration cycle to protect the timber.<br>
<br>
Overall, the external doors and frames are functional and adequately secure, though minor upgrading is required to meet current fire safety and access standards.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The external doors, frames, and locking arrangements are in adequate condition for their age. Both the main entrance and rear fire exit doors are functional and secure, but the locking mechanisms should be upgraded to thumb-turn types for compliance with modern fire safety requirements. All timber components require repainting within two years to maintain weather protection. Subject to these upgrades and periodic redecoration, the doors and frames should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to repaint or modernise the locking systems could result in security issues, timber decay, and non-compliance with current fire safety standards.</div>

The same goes for reinforcement works such as underpinning, which is carried out because of subsidence. The foundations of this property would typically be brick footings on a concrete strip sub-foundation. Nowadays, foundations are often designed to counteract soil behaviour. However, older foundations such as period corbelled footings are shallow, increasing the risk of subsidence. The subsidence risk assessment is made based on the soil type, foundation design and the current management of the soil. Our findings may differ from those of a third party, which provides a generic area-based risk assessment. (See section 9.1 Soil Type and Subsidence Risk).</div>

            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671547" class="ng-binding">
                    Limitations of Interior Inspection
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671547-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">KITCHEN CABINETS<br>
The presence of cabinets affixed against the kitchen walls restricted a comprehensive evaluation of the concealed wall areas. These cabinets, while functional for storage, can obscure potential issues like dampness or structural damage in the wall behind them.<br>
<br>
FLOOR COVERINGS<br>
The floor coverings, securely fitted onto the floors, were not removed during the survey. As a result, the exact nature of the underlying materials and any potential defects remain undetermined. Despite this, an assessment of the floors' sturdiness and levelness was conducted, offering some insight into their general condition.<br>
<br>
FURNITURE AND FITTINGS<br>
Large pieces of furniture, fixtures, and fittings placed against the walls were not relocated for the survey. This limitation hindered the thorough inspection of the walls for issues like dampness or structural damage.<br>
<br>
RECOMMENDATIONS AND NEXT STEPS<br>
Given these limitations, it is advisable to arrange for a follow-up inspection once the vendor has cleared the moveable items. This subsequent survey can offer a more detailed evaluation of previously inaccessible areas. If you wish for us to undertake this additional inspection, please be aware that a fee will be applicable.<br>
<br>
LIMITATIONS OF THE ASSESSMENT<br>
It's important to note that the accessibility of areas within the property constrains this survey's scope. Our assessment is based on the visible and accessible elements at the time of inspection. Inaccessible areas may conceal defects that are not apparent in this initial survey.<br>
<br>
For a comprehensive understanding of the property's condition, a full inspection, including these previously inaccessible areas, is recommended. The decision to proceed with this additional inspection should be based on the client's discretion and in consultation with their legal and real estate advisors. The client should weigh the potential benefits of uncovering hidden issues against the associated costs of the additional survey.</div>

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->

                    Ceilings
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671550-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The ceilings throughout the flat are of reinforced concrete construction, typical of 1930s apartment buildings, providing good structural integrity and fire resistance. Most ceilings are finished with plaster and decorated either with smooth paint, lining paper, or textured coatings. The textured finishes observed in the hallway, bedrooms, and possibly beneath later decorations in the kitchen may contain asbestos, as textured coatings of this era often included chrysotile fibres. These surfaces should be tested by a UKAS-accredited asbestos laboratory before any sanding, drilling, or redecoration is carried out. If confirmed to contain asbestos, the material can safely remain in place if undisturbed and in good condition, but must be managed under an asbestos management plan.<br>
<br>
The ceiling surfaces are generally even and free from cracking, staining, or signs of movement. Minor hairline cracks were noted above the chimney breast in the living room and are consistent with normal thermal expansion rather than any structural defect. These can be filled during routine decoration. No sagging or hollow areas were evident, confirming the ceilings remain well bonded to the concrete substrate.<br>
<br>
In the kitchen and bathroom, the concrete ceilings have been repainted and show some minor peeling near ventilation points where condensation has accumulated. This is superficial and can be corrected during redecoration once ventilation improvements are made.<br>
<br>
No evidence of leaks, water staining, or dampness was seen on any ceiling surfaces, suggesting that the roof and upper plumbing installations are performing effectively. The previous historic leak in the communal hallway was dry at the time of inspection and had not affected the flat‚Äôs internal ceilings.<br>
<br>
Lighting installations vary between rooms. Some ceiling-mounted fittings have been removed, leaving redundant conduit tracks visible. These areas are safe but should be made good by a qualified electrician prior to refitting new light points.<br>
<br>
The ceilings are of durable construction and should provide a serviceable lifespan well in excess of ten years, subject to normal redecoration and environmental control.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The ceilings are in adequate condition with no evidence of structural defect or water damage. Textured coatings may contain asbestos and must be tested before disturbance. Minor cracking and peeling are purely decorative and can be addressed during routine redecoration. Subject to asbestos management and improved ventilation in moisture-prone rooms, the ceilings should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to test or manage potential asbestos-containing finishes before work could result in health and regulatory risks.</div>

        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671551" class="ng-binding">
                    Interior Walls and Energy Efficiency
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671551-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The internal walls within the flat are of solid masonry construction, consistent with the property‚Äôs 1930s concrete-framed design. The walls are plastered and decorated with a mixture of painted plaster and lining paper finishes. In most rooms, the wall surfaces appeared level and well bonded, with no significant cracking or bulging. Hairline cracks were noted in the living room near the chimney breast, which are minor thermal movement cracks and do not indicate structural concern. These can be repaired with filler before redecoration.<br>
<br>
The plaster finishes throughout the flat are likely to be traditional gypsum or lime plaster applied directly to the masonry. These finishes have a long life expectancy when kept dry, typically exceeding 30 years. Some slight peeling of paint and paper was noted in the kitchen and around window reveals, consistent with localised condensation and normal age-related wear. The lower sections of the bathroom walls also exhibited peeling paint due to high humidity and the absence of an extractor fan. The installation of a suitable fan should be arranged now to control condensation and protect the plaster surfaces from further deterioration.<br>
<br>
The internal partitions between rooms are of solid masonry in most areas, which provides good acoustic and fire resistance. These walls are robust but not insulated, meaning that the property will feel cooler to the touch compared with modern insulated constructions. The partitions appeared plumb and stable, with no visible cracking that would suggest movement.<br>
<br>
Decoration throughout the flat is dated but serviceable. The finishes in the kitchen and bathroom would benefit from renewal using moisture-resistant paint systems. The living and bedroom walls can be redecorated as desired for aesthetic reasons. The estimated remaining life of the current decorative finishes is up to five years, subject to normal use and humidity levels.<br>
<br>
There is no evidence of structural alteration to load-bearing walls. The living and dining areas have been opened into one larger room; the opening has been framed in timber and appears stable, suggesting it may have been carried out as part of a historic refurbishment. Any alterations to load-bearing walls in such buildings require structural engineer approval and Building Regulation consent. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm that the necessary consents were obtained.<br>
<br>
Party walls separating the flat from adjoining dwellings are assumed to be of solid masonry construction and provide good fire and acoustic separation in accordance with the standards applicable at the time of construction. If any future alterations are proposed that may affect these walls, such as chasing for new services or removing plaster, a party wall notice would be required under the Party Wall etc. Act 1996.<br>
<br>
Thermally, the flat performs modestly by modern standards. According to the accompanying Energy Performance Certificate, the dwelling currently has an energy efficiency rating of 61 (Band D) with a potential rating of 76 (Band C). The walls are solid brick with no insulation and are categorised as ‚Äúvery poor‚Äù in thermal performance. The absence of insulation results in higher heat loss through the perimeter walls, particularly on exposed elevations. The roof and floor, being adjacent to other dwellings, provide some benefit from shared heat transfer.<br>
<br>
To improve thermal performance, internal wall insulation (IWI) can be considered, typically in the form of insulated plasterboard or mineral wool between battens. Such upgrades would need to be vapour-controlled to avoid condensation between the insulation and the cold wall surface. This work would require Building Control approval under Part L of the Building Regulations. External wall insulation (EWI) would not be suitable in this context, as it would alter the appearance of the block and require freeholder consent.<br>
<br>
Other recommended energy upgrades include reinstating open ventilation grilles in the kitchen and bathroom, as these have been painted over, and fitting low-energy LED lighting to replace conventional fittings. The EPC also indicates that the community heating system lacks individual thermostatic control, meaning room temperatures cannot be regulated efficiently. If the management company upgrades the communal system in future, installation of thermostatic radiator valves within each flat would offer improved energy control and comfort.<br>
<br>
The flat benefits from concrete floors and ceilings that assist with heat retention between levels, but the walls remain the principal route of heat loss. Draughts are also likely to occur around older steel window frames; sealing gaps and fitting secondary glazing or draught-proofing strips would improve comfort without altering the building‚Äôs external appearance.<br>
<br>
Given the flat‚Äôs construction type and current EPC results, significant thermal improvement beyond a mid-range Band C would be difficult without substantial wall insulation and heating control upgrades. However, the building remains reasonably efficient for its age, and the energy performance is typical of similar 1930s flats.<br>
<br>
The plaster and masonry wall finishes are expected to remain serviceable for ten or more years provided moisture levels are managed through improved ventilation and periodic redecoration.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The internal walls and finishes are in adequate condition, showing only minor decorative wear. Structural stability is sound, and no significant cracking was evident. Condensation-related deterioration in the kitchen and bathroom must be addressed by improving ventilation and redecorating with moisture-resistant paint. The energy efficiency of the flat is fair for its age but limited by uninsulated solid walls. Improvements such as internal wall insulation, reinstating ventilation grilles, and installing thermostatic radiator controls would enhance comfort and reduce energy costs. Subject to these minor upgrades and normal maintenance, the internal walls and finishes will remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to manage moisture or ventilation could lead to peeling finishes, surface mould, and higher heating bills.</div>

    </div><!-- end ngRepeat: reportItem in vm.reportItems --><div ng-repeat="reportItem in vm.reportItems" class="reportItem ng-scope" id="template-item-14975">
    <a name="1671552" id="report-item-1671552"></a>
    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671552" class="ng-binding">
                    Floors
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">
    <input type="checkbox" href="#" class="menu-open" name="menu-open" ng-class="{'toggle': vm.optionsOpen}" id="menu-open">
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected === null -->
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected !== null --><label class="menu-open-button rating ng-binding ng-scope" ng-if="vm.currentlySelected !== null" ng-style="{'background': vm.currentlySelected['shape-fill'], 'color': vm.currentlySelected['label-colour'] }" for="menu-open" ng-click="vm.toggleOptions()" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">

    <a uib-tooltip="No rating" tooltip-append-to-body="true" ng-click="vm.selectOption(null)" class="menu-item rating unselected">
    </a>

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
