</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671552-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Calculations of the load-bearing capacity of floors were not carried out, and I can give no opinion on their strength or suitability for your purposes. <br>
<br>
The floors throughout the flat are of solid concrete construction at the substructure level, with timber strip flooring laid over in most habitable rooms. This is a typical arrangement for 1930s concrete-framed apartment blocks, providing a robust and fire-resistant base while allowing a more comfortable decorative finish within each flat. Concrete floors are extremely durable and require minimal maintenance apart from surface finishes, with an expected lifespan of over 50 years. The suspended timber boarding provides aesthetic appeal and a warmer surface underfoot but does require regular care to prevent shrinkage, creaking, or surface wear.<br>
<br>
In the hallway and living areas, the flooring consists of natural timber strip boards. The boards were noted to creak slightly when walked on, which is typical of aged floorboards laid over concrete or battens. The movement is minor and likely due to loosening of the mechanical fixings over time. Securing the boards with additional nails or screws will usually resolve the issue. No evidence of deflection, bounce, or rot was noted, suggesting that the floor structure remains firm and stable.<br>
<br>
In the kitchen, bathroom, and WC, the floors are formed entirely of concrete with continuous vinyl coverings. These surfaces appeared level and adequately bonded. The vinyl flooring in both the kitchen and bathroom was in adequate condition, showing only minor surface wear. The seams appeared watertight, offering effective protection against moisture penetration. Vinyl finishes in wet areas should be checked regularly for lifting edges or splits, as moisture can seep through and damage the subfloor or cause mould growth at junctions. Re-sealing or replacement should be considered if deterioration is observed.<br>
<br>
The floor in the bathroom cupboard is bare timber, possibly an older section that was left unfinished when the cupboard was converted from a service riser. The exposed timber should be treated with a moisture-resistant sealant or overlaid with a suitable floor covering to prevent damp penetration and make cleaning easier.<br>
<br>
The front entry area, being part of the communal concrete floor slab, was even and solid. There was a visible crack in the external step immediately outside the front door, which is separate from the flat‚Äôs internal floor structure and likely due to differential settlement of concrete sections. This has no bearing on the internal stability but should be repaired during the next maintenance cycle for safety and appearance.<br>
<br>
The internal floors are assumed to have no timber void beneath, as the building type typically features concrete slabs between levels. This means that subfloor ventilation is not applicable, and the risk of hidden timber decay is minimal. However, it also means that the structure can feel cold and transmit impact noise between flats. The presence of a district heating system will help maintain even floor temperatures, but fitting sound-absorbing underlay beneath any future floor coverings would improve acoustic comfort.<br>
<br>
The overall condition of the floors is adequate for their age and construction type. No evidence of significant movement, settlement, or moisture ingress was found. The finishes are largely serviceable, although minor improvement works such as securing loose boards and resealing vinyl joints would enhance durability.<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of the concrete subfloors is 10+ years, while the timber strip flooring has an estimated remaining life of around five to ten years depending on use and maintenance. Routine cleaning, avoidance of water spillage, and re-finishing with protective sealant or varnish will extend its life considerably.<br>
<br>
Given that this is a leasehold property, the structural concrete floors are the responsibility of the freeholder or management company, while maintenance of decorative floor finishes within the flat rests with the individual leaseholder. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should confirm this distinction in the lease documentation.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The floors throughout the flat are performing adequately, with the concrete subfloors providing long-term stability and the timber strip flooring offering an attractive surface finish. Minor creaking in the hallway should be addressed by re-fixing the boards, and the vinyl in the kitchen and bathroom should be monitored for joint lifting. No structural issues were detected. Subject to minor repairs and regular maintenance, the floors should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to secure loose boards or reseal vinyl joints could lead to surface deterioration and water ingress into the flooring system, which would be more costly to repair later.</div>

    </div><!-- end ngRepeat: reportItem in vm.reportItems --><div ng-repeat="reportItem in vm.reportItems" class="reportItem ng-scope" id="template-item-14976">
    <a name="1671553" id="report-item-1671553"></a>
    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671553" class="ng-binding">
                    Internal Doors and Fire Resistance
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">
    <input type="checkbox" href="#" class="menu-open" name="menu-open" ng-class="{'toggle': vm.optionsOpen}" id="menu-open">
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected === null -->
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected !== null --><label class="menu-open-button rating ng-binding ng-scope" ng-if="vm.currentlySelected !== null" ng-style="{'background': vm.currentlySelected['shape-fill'], 'color': vm.currentlySelected['label-colour'] }" for="menu-open" ng-click="vm.toggleOptions()" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </label><!-- end ngIf: vm.currentlySelected !== null -->

    <a uib-tooltip="No rating" tooltip-append-to-body="true" ng-click="vm.selectOption(null)" class="menu-item rating unselected">
    </a>

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671553-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The internal doors throughout the flat are of hollow-core or honeycomb timber construction, typical of post-war refurbishments to 1930s blocks. These lightweight doors are functional for general domestic use but offer limited sound insulation and only minimal fire resistance compared with modern FD-rated doors. The door frames, architraves, and linings are all timber and generally well-fitted, showing no signs of distortion or decay. Paint finishes are intact but dated and could benefit from redecoration for appearance and durability.<br>
<br>
The flat‚Äôs entrance door to the communal hallway is a timber fire door incorporating Georgian wired glass. This type of door provides a reasonable level of fire resistance‚Äîhistorically rated at around 30 minutes (FD30)‚Äîbut the current installation falls short of modern standards. The door was observed to have only two hinges and lacked an overhead self-closing device. The absence of a self-closer compromises both fire safety and compartmentation, as the door may be left ajar in an emergency. An approved hydraulic closer and intumescent strips should be installed now by a qualified fire door contractor to ensure the door performs as a compliant FD30S (fire and smoke-rated) door.<br>
<br>
The entry door is fitted with two key-operated deadlocks, which, while secure, present a safety risk in an emergency as they require keys to exit. These must be replaced with thumb-turn locks that comply with BS 8621 standards, allowing egress without keys while maintaining external security. The replacement should be carried out by a qualified locksmith familiar with fire door safety requirements.<br>
<br>
The internal doors leading to the bedrooms, bathroom, WC, and kitchen are hollow-core doors fitted into timber frames. They appear to close properly within their rebates but would not meet modern fire resistance standards. Hollow-core doors typically offer only 10‚Äì15 minutes of resistance and lack smoke seals. In a flat, where internal compartmentation is critical, these doors should ideally be upgraded to FD30-rated doors fitted with intumescent strips and smoke seals. This is particularly important for the kitchen, which is classed as a high fire-risk area due to cooking appliances and proximity to the means of escape.<br>
<br>
The kitchen door has been removed, leaving an open doorway to the hallway. This significantly reduces fire protection between the kitchen and escape route and does not comply with current Building Regulations. A new FD30S fire-rated door with intumescent strips and a self-closing mechanism must be installed now to restore proper separation. This measure will contain smoke and flame in the event of a kitchen fire and protect the primary escape route.<br>
<br>
The bathroom and WC doors are honeycomb-style types and in adequate decorative condition. As these are not considered fire compartmentation doors, replacement with fire-rated doors is not essential unless major refurbishment is planned. However, all internal doors should be adjusted to close fully within their frames, and worn hinges or latches replaced to maintain proper operation.<br>
<br>
The overall fire compartmentation between rooms appears consistent with the property‚Äôs period, but modern standards require higher resistance, particularly at the flat entrance and between the kitchen and hallway. All internal door upgrades should be carried out by a certified carpenter or fire door installer to ensure compliance with Building Regulations Approved Document B.<br>
<br>
Decoratively, all internal doors would benefit from light sanding and redecoration to refresh appearance and seal exposed edges. Repainting should be done using a fire-retardant paint system where possible, especially for the flat entrance and kitchen door, to provide additional protection.<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of the existing hollow-core doors is around five years, subject to use and maintenance. The entrance door, once upgraded with modern hardware and closers, should provide a remaining service life of ten or more years.<br>
<br>
As this is a leasehold property, the flat‚Äôs entrance door is usually classed as a communal fire-safety element under the freeholder‚Äôs or management company‚Äôs responsibility. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm this and ensure that the door meets current fire safety standards and that the building has undergone a recent Fire Risk Assessment as required under the Fire Safety (England) Regulations 2022.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The internal doors are serviceable for general use but do not meet modern fire resistance standards. The flat entrance door requires immediate upgrading with an overhead self-closer, intumescent strips, and thumb-turn locks to achieve FD30S compliance. The missing kitchen door must be reinstated now as an FD30S door to protect the escape route. Other internal hollow-core doors may remain but should be upgraded during future refurbishment. Subject to these essential safety improvements, the door sets will remain functional for up to ten years. Failure to complete the recommended fire safety upgrades would leave the property non-compliant with current fire safety guidance and could compromise escape in the event of a fire.</div>

                <div class="col-xs-12">

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->
                </div>
            </div><!-- end ngIf: vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes' -->

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671554-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The internal woodwork and trims within the flat comprise original and later softwood joinery, including skirting boards, architraves, window boards, door linings, and picture rails. These features are typical of 1930s construction and contribute to the period character of the property. The joinery appears largely original, with some later replacements around door frames and kitchen areas. The timber surfaces are painted, and most finishes remain intact, though some areas are aged and show minor wear, consistent with the age of the building.<br>
<br>
The skirting boards are softwood, finished with multiple layers of paint. They appeared securely fixed and adequately aligned against the plastered walls, with no evidence of rot or separation from the wall base. In the hallway and around internal corners, there were small gaps where the boards have pulled slightly due to seasonal movement. These are minor cosmetic issues that can be remedied by re-fixing or sealing during redecoration. The existing paintwork is thick and may conceal early decorative layers that contain lead-based paint, which is common in pre-1970s buildings. When redecorating, surfaces should not be dry-sanded or heat-stripped; instead, a wet-sanding technique or encapsulating paint system should be used to minimise dust and health risks.<br>
<br>
Architraves and door frames are generally of the same softwood material and are in adequate condition. Minor dents and paint wear were observed around door handles and hinges, typical of regular use. There is no evidence of woodworm, fungal decay, or moisture staining on any internal woodwork. The paint surfaces have yellowed slightly over time, suggesting oil-based coatings, which can be overcoated with modern water-based paints for a brighter finish. Redecoration every five to seven years will maintain appearance and surface protection.<br>
<br>
The window boards beneath the Critall steel frames are timber and have areas of flaking paint and localised surface decay, especially in the kitchen and bedrooms. These boards are exposed to condensation from the single-glazed steel windows and occasional rainwater penetration through small frame gaps. The affected sections should be rubbed down, repaired with a two-part epoxy filler or spliced with treated softwood where decay is deeper, then repainted with a durable microporous system to prevent further moisture damage. This work should be completed within the next twelve months.<br>
<br>
Timber trims in the kitchen, such as cupboard liners and skirting beneath the units, appeared serviceable but worn. Repainting or replacing with modern moisture-resistant MDF or PVC skirting during future kitchen refurbishment would improve hygiene and longevity. Timber trims near water sources should always be sealed to prevent swelling and surface rot.<br>
<br>
Picture rails and mouldings remain in place in some rooms and add to the flat‚Äôs period character. These are stable but would benefit from redecoration to match the walls and ceiling finishes. If removed or replaced, care should be taken not to damage the plaster beneath, as original plaster surfaces are brittle.<br>
<br>
Overall, the timber joinery is in adequate condition, showing only superficial wear consistent with age. The materials remain serviceable and have an estimated remaining lifespan of 10+ years, provided periodic redecoration and minor repairs are undertaken. Where window boards show early decay, localised repairs should be carried out within a year to prevent further deterioration.<br>
<br>
As the property is leasehold, responsibility for internal joinery within the flat rests entirely with the leaseholder. External joinery, such as communal door frames and sills, would typically fall under the freeholder or management company‚Äôs maintenance obligations. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should confirm these divisions in the lease documentation.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The internal woodwork and trims remain in generally adequate condition, with only minor decorative deterioration and localised paint failure noted. The window boards require early repair and redecoration to prevent progression of decay caused by condensation. Other joinery components are sound and will provide long service life if maintained through regular painting every five to seven years. Failure to redecorate or seal vulnerable sections could result in localised timber rot and the need for more extensive replacement later. Subject to normal maintenance, the internal timber joinery should remain fully serviceable for at least ten years.</div>

    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings -->
</nav><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false -->
</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671555-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The kitchen is fitted with a range of mid- to late-20th-century base and wall units of laminated chipboard construction. The units are functional but of dated appearance and modest quality, with visible signs of age and wear. Laminated chipboard is economical but susceptible to swelling and delamination when exposed to prolonged moisture, especially around sink areas and appliance joints. The worktops are similarly formed in laminated chipboard with plastic edging strips, which remain largely intact but show minor surface wear. The overall installation is functional but nearing the end of its cosmetic life, with an estimated remaining lifespan of five years subject to routine maintenance.<br>
<br>
The worktop height is approximately 940 mm, which is higher than the current standard (about 910 mm). While not a defect, this could make use less convenient for some occupants. If the kitchen is refurbished in future, the height should be adjusted to standard levels for comfort and safety. The layout also appears inefficient, with limited workspace and no provision for wall units on certain walls. Reconfiguration could improve usability and storage.<br>
<br>
All units appeared dry internally and free from active water leaks. The area beneath the sink and dishwasher was inspected and found to be dry, although some staining suggests historic minor leaks. Sealing around the sink and along worktop joints should be renewed within the next twelve months to prevent further moisture ingress. The sink unit is stainless steel and remains serviceable.<br>
<br>
The plumbing beneath the sink comprises copper supply pipes and uPVC waste fittings, both modern and in adequate condition. There was no evidence of active leakage. The presence of supplementary bonding to the pipework was noted, which is correct practice for electrical safety.<br>
<br>
The floor covering in the kitchen is continuous vinyl laid over the concrete floor. It appeared secure and cleanable, offering adequate slip resistance. This material performs well in wet areas but should be resealed at joints during future maintenance to prevent moisture migration beneath.<br>
<br>
The kitchen ceiling contains recessed spotlights connected to the consumer unit. The fittings appeared modern and functional, but it should be confirmed that all are fire-rated downlights with properly sealed enclosures, especially where installed in ceilings adjoining escape routes.<br>
<br>
There is currently no door fitted between the kitchen and hallway, which is a significant fire safety concern. Kitchens are classed as high fire-risk areas, and an FD30S (fire-rated and smoke-sealed) door must be reinstated now to maintain safe compartmentation and protect the escape route. This work should be carried out by a qualified joiner or fire-door installer.<br>
<br>
The wall surfaces include a section of timber tongue-and-groove cladding between the kitchen and bathroom wall. This is unsuitable for a kitchen environment, as it is combustible and can absorb moisture and grease. It should be replaced with a tiled or heat-resistant glass splashback during the next refurbishment. Painted plaster finishes elsewhere are dated, with some peeling around window reveals due to condensation. Redecoration with washable, moisture-resistant paint is recommended.<br>
<br>
The kitchen window is a Critall steel-framed unit with single glazing. Surface corrosion was observed, and the window sits high above the sink, making operation difficult. Corrosion should be treated and repainted as described in the window section. The high window position may not comply with modern ergonomic standards but presents no structural issue.<br>
<br>
Electrical fittings in the kitchen include modern sockets and a consumer unit located within the base unit. The consumer unit is of the 17th-Edition type with RCBOs, installed in August 2021, and appears compliant and in good order. Electrical safety testing should nonetheless be carried out every five years by a qualified electrician.<br>
<br>
The overall quality of the kitchen installation is dated but serviceable. The units are nearing the end of their practical life and would benefit from full replacement during future modernisation. If refurbished, the use of moisture-resistant carcasses, sealed worktops, fire-rated finishes, and energy-efficient appliances would improve durability and performance.<br>
<br>
Responsibility for kitchen fixtures and fittings rests solely with the leaseholder. Any plumbing or electrical alterations must comply with current Building Regulations (Approved Documents G and P for plumbing and Part P for electrical safety).<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of the current kitchen units and worktops is approximately five years, subject to regular cleaning and re-sealing. Plumbing and electrical components, if maintained, should remain serviceable for ten or more years.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The kitchen fittings are functional but dated and showing typical age-related wear. The lack of a kitchen door is a fire-safety concern that must be rectified immediately by installing an FD30S fire door. Minor re-sealing is required around the sink to prevent moisture damage, and combustible timber cladding should be replaced with a tiled or heat-resistant finish. Full kitchen refurbishment should be considered within five years to improve usability, safety, and efficiency. Failure to maintain sealants and finishes could result in moisture-related swelling of units, deterioration of worktops, and reduced hygiene standards.</div>

    </div><!-- end ngRepeat: reportItem in vm.reportItems --><div ng-repeat="reportItem in vm.reportItems" class="reportItem ng-scope" id="template-item-14979">
    <a name="1671556" id="report-item-1671556"></a>
    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671556" class="ng-binding">
                    Sanitary Fixtures and Fittings
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected === null -->
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected !== null --><label class="menu-open-button rating ng-binding ng-scope" ng-if="vm.currentlySelected !== null" ng-style="{'background': vm.currentlySelected['shape-fill'], 'color': vm.currentlySelected['label-colour'] }" for="menu-open" ng-click="vm.toggleOptions()" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671556-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The bathroom and WC are fitted with original or early replacement sanitary fixtures typical of mid-twentieth-century installations. In the main bathroom, there is a pressed-steel bathtub with a white enamel finish, an old ceramic wash basin with pillar taps, and a separate WC located in its own compartment. The fixtures remain functional but are dated and showing age-related wear.<br>
<br>
The steel bath exhibits corrosion and enamel loss around the waste outlet, with visible rust staining. This type of deterioration occurs when enamel chips allow water to reach the metal substrate, eventually leading to pin-holing and leakage. The bath is serviceable at present but should be replaced within the next two years to prevent further corrosion and potential failure. Modern acrylic or steel-enamel replacements would provide improved insulation and ease of maintenance.<br>
<br>
The joint between the bath and wall is sealed using quadrant tile beading and sealant, which currently appears watertight but is not the most durable method. Over time, rigid tile trims can crack with movement, leading to water ingress behind tiles. The seal should be checked periodically and resealed with flexible silicone as soon as gaps or cracking appear.<br>
<br>
The wash basin is of ceramic construction with pillar taps and a pedestal base, showing minor wear consistent with age. Rusty discolouration was noted in the hot tap water, likely originating from corrosion in the communal steel supply pipework or storage tanks. This issue should be monitored and reported to the building‚Äôs management company, as the communal water supply falls under their maintenance responsibility. If corrosion persists, the affected pipework should be renewed by a qualified plumber.<br>
<br>
The bathroom drainage is slow at the bath, which suggests partial blockage or reduced ventilation in the cast-iron waste stack. This should be inspected by a plumber to clear deposits and check the air admittance system. The drainage to the basin and WC otherwise functioned adequately during testing.<br>
<br>
There is no mechanical extractor fan in the bathroom; only a passive wall vent was noted, which is painted over and therefore ineffective. The lack of extraction allows condensation to accumulate, causing peeling paint and encouraging mould growth. A mechanical extractor fan ducted to the outside should be installed now by a qualified electrician to improve ventilation and protect finishes.<br>
<br>
The towel radiator is a tubular chrome-plated steel type connected to the central heating system. It was noted to lack secure upper brackets, making it vulnerable to strain on the compression fittings. The radiator should be refixed firmly to the wall now by a heating engineer to prevent leaks and maintain safe operation.<br>
<br>
The separate WC room contains a low-level ceramic pan and cistern connected to a cast-iron soil pipe. The pan connector exhibits surface corrosion, likely from condensation. Although it remains intact, corrosion should be cleaned and treated with an anti-rust primer, and the joint re-sealed during the next maintenance cycle. The cistern is functioning, though the internal fill valve emits a dripping sound after use, which can be rectified by fitting a plastic sleeve to the fill pipe or replacing the valve assembly.<br>
<br>
The WC lacks a hand-wash basin, which is below current hygiene standards. A compact combined WC and basin unit could be installed within the existing space to improve sanitation without major alteration.<br>
<br>
All sanitary fittings are connected to copper supply and uPVC waste pipes, which are appropriate modern materials and in adequate condition. No leaks were identified at the time of inspection.<br>
<br>
The overall condition of the sanitary fittings is functional but aged. The components show normal wear for their age, with corrosion and dated finishes detracting from long-term reliability. Replacement of the bath and installation of a mechanical extractor should be considered within the next two years.<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of the existing sanitary fixtures is between two and five years, depending on usage and maintenance.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The sanitary fittings are functioning but dated and approaching the end of their serviceable life. The steel bath exhibits corrosion and should be replaced within two years. The lack of mechanical extraction is a significant defect and must be rectified now to control condensation and prevent further deterioration of finishes. The towel radiator should be securely refixed immediately, and the WC cistern valve adjusted to prevent dripping. Upgrading the fixtures during future refurbishment would enhance durability, water efficiency, and hygiene. Failure to address these issues could result in leaks, ongoing condensation problems, and costly redecoration of adjacent surfaces.</div>

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671557-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Storage fittings within the flat consist mainly of built-in cupboards, timber shelving, and integrated storage spaces adapted from the original layout. These are characteristic of 1930s apartment design, where concrete-framed structures allowed masonry cupboard enclosures within the internal walls. The primary storage areas include a hallway cupboard, a bathroom cupboard, and shelving within alcoves in the main rooms.<br>
<br>
The hallway cupboard, formerly a services cupboard, has been repurposed for general storage. It contains the old gas supply pipework, which is now capped off. The internal walls are painted plaster and appeared in good condition with no signs of dampness or staining. The door is a hollow-core timber type that closes adequately within its frame. The cupboard is dry, well-ventilated, and suitable for continued domestic use. However, because it contains capped gas pipework, it should not be used to store flammable items such as paint, solvents, or aerosols.<br>
<br>
In the bathroom, a small built-in cupboard was noted. This cupboard is constructed with masonry blockwork and fitted with timber shelving and a hollow-core timber door. The shelving was serviceable, although the bare timber flooring inside should be sealed or overlaid with a washable covering to prevent moisture absorption. The cupboard contained exposed communal pipework serving the basin and bath, which appeared in adequate condition and free from leaks. The cupboard is suitable for storage of non-perishable items but should not be used for towels or fabrics unless the ventilation within the bathroom is improved, as humidity levels can lead to mould growth on stored items.<br>
<br>
There is no evidence of modern fitted wardrobes or purpose-built cabinetry in the bedrooms. Freestanding furniture is currently used for storage. The introduction of built-in wardrobes would be possible along internal walls, but care must be taken not to restrict ventilation or conceal junctions where condensation may form, particularly along cold external walls.<br>
<br>
In the kitchen, shelving is fitted in place of wall cupboards. While functional, this provides limited dust protection and is not ideal for storing food or cooking equipment. Replacement with closed wall units would be a practical improvement during future refurbishment. The existing open shelves are timber and remain securely fixed, but paint finishes are worn and should be redecorated for hygiene and appearance.<br>
<br>
All storage fittings appear structurally adequate and free from damage. The doors close correctly, and there is no evidence of decay or infestation. Paint finishes throughout are dated but serviceable. Redecoration with washable, light-coloured paint would improve brightness and cleanliness, particularly inside the hallway and bathroom cupboards.<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of the existing storage fittings is in excess of ten years, provided regular cleaning, redecoration, and ventilation are maintained. Minor works such as sealing timber shelving and improving ventilation in humid areas should be completed within the next year.<br>
<br>
Responsibility for the maintenance of these fittings rests with the leaseholder. Any works involving the removal or alteration of cupboard walls should be carefully assessed to ensure that no service ducts or structural elements are affected.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The storage fittings are functional and in adequate condition, showing only minor wear consistent with age. The cupboards are dry and structurally stable but require redecoration for cleanliness and improved appearance. The hallway cupboard should not be used to store flammable materials due to the presence of capped gas pipework, and ventilation should be improved in the bathroom cupboard to prevent condensation and mould. Subject to these minor adjustments and routine maintenance, the storage fittings will remain serviceable for at least ten years. Neglecting ventilation or redecoration could lead to localised mould growth and deterioration of stored items.</div>

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671566-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property is fitted with a single battery-operated smoke alarm located within the flat, which is functional but below the current recommended standard for a multi-storey, multi-occupancy building. There was no evidence of an integrated fire alarm or heat detection system serving the individual flat or the communal areas. A correctly installed fire detection system is a vital life safety feature, particularly in older leasehold buildings of this type.<br>
<br>
Current fire safety guidance for dwellings (BS 5839-6:2019) recommends that flats have a Grade D1 or D2, Category LD2 system. This requires interlinked mains-powered smoke alarms with integral backup batteries installed in circulation spaces such as hallways, and a heat detector in the kitchen. The single standalone battery detector currently present provides only basic protection and is not interlinked, meaning it will not alert occupants in adjoining areas or other flats. An upgraded mains-powered, interlinked system must therefore be installed now by a qualified electrician or fire alarm contractor.<br>
<br>
No fire alarm sounders or detectors were noted in the communal staircase or landings serving the building. This is a concern, as the property forms part of a four-storey block of flats. While some older buildings operate on a ‚Äústay put‚Äù policy with no communal alarm, modern standards under the Fire Safety (England) Regulations 2022 require that a competent fire risk assessor confirms whether the existing arrangement is appropriate and ensures adequate warning measures are in place. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm through the freeholder or management company whether a recent Fire Risk Assessment has been completed and whether the absence of a communal alarm system is compliant with the building‚Äôs current fire strategy.<br>
<br>
A mains-wired emergency light fitting was noted on the third floor, though one of the fittings was out of service at the time of inspection. Emergency lighting is essential for safe evacuation and should be maintained under a routine testing schedule by the management company.<br>
<br>
There is no evidence of any fire suppression system such as sprinklers, misting systems, or fire blankets within the flat. Although not a regulatory requirement for existing buildings of this age, it would be prudent to install a fire blanket in the kitchen, mounted near the exit door, and to keep a small, BS-EN3-certified dry powder or CO‚ÇÇ extinguisher near the entrance. Sprinkler or mist systems are not typically expected in 1930s conversions unless the building undergoes major refurbishment.<br>
<br>
Given the absence of an interlinked fire alarm and the building‚Äôs multi-occupancy nature, a comprehensive fire safety upgrade is recommended immediately. The installation should include a mains-wired smoke alarm in the hallway, a heat detector in the kitchen, and interlinking between devices to provide full early-warning coverage. All devices should comply with BS EN 14604 and be installed by a qualified NICEIC-registered contractor.<br>
<br>
The existing smoke alarm is likely to be older than five years. Even if operational, all domestic smoke alarms have a typical lifespan of ten years before sensor degradation reduces effectiveness. Replacement with modern interlinked devices is strongly advised now.<br>
<br>
The expected service life of a new mains-powered alarm system is around ten years, with annual testing and battery checks required as part of normal maintenance.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The current smoke alarm provision is inadequate for a leasehold flat within a multi-occupancy block. The single standalone battery alarm must be upgraded now to a mains-powered, interlinked smoke and heat detection system meeting BS 5839-6 standards. The absence of a communal alarm system should be reviewed through the management company‚Äôs Fire Risk Assessment, and any defective emergency lighting must be repaired immediately. A kitchen fire blanket should also be provided. Subject to these urgent upgrades and routine maintenance, the property‚Äôs fire detection measures can achieve an adequate level of safety. Failure to undertake these works leaves occupants at significant risk in the event of fire and may place the building in breach of current fire safety regulations.</div>

                <div class="col-xs-12">

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->
                </div>
            </div><!-- end ngIf: vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes' -->

        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== 'Table' && reportItem.ItemType !== 'Section Heading' && reportItem.ItemType !== 'RICS Summary Table' && reportItem.ItemType !== 'Fixed Row Table' && reportItem.ItemType !== 'GVA Summary Table' && reportItem.ItemType !== 'GVA Summary Table' -->
    </div><!-- Close Row -->

    </div><!-- end ngRepeat: reportItem in vm.reportItems --><div ng-repeat="reportItem in vm.reportItems" class="reportItem ng-scope" id="template-item-14990">
    <a name="1671567" id="report-item-1671567"></a>
    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671567" class="ng-binding">
                    Water Supply and Plumbing
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671567-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property is connected to the mains water supply, which is distributed through communal pipework serving the block before entering the individual flat. The supply within the flat is primarily copper for the internal branch pipes, with uPVC waste pipework serving appliances and sanitary fittings. The internal visible pipework is of mixed age but appeared in generally adequate condition, with no active leaks noted during inspection.<br>
<br>
The original supply route to the flat passes through the former services cupboard in the hallway, where the original steel barrel gas and water pipes remain visible. The gas pipe has been capped off, and no active gas meter is present. The water supply appears to have been upgraded at some point to copper, although some original steel pipe sections may remain concealed within walls or floors. Steel water pipes are prone to internal corrosion over time, leading to reduced flow rates, rusty discolouration, and potential leaks. Evidence of rust-coloured water from the hot tap in the bathroom suggests some corrosion within the communal cold-water tank or residual steel sections of the supply system. The management company should arrange for investigation and, if necessary, replacement of corroded steel supply pipework.<br>
<br>
Water pressure at outlets was generally adequate. The flow from both the basin and kitchen sink taps was reasonable, although slight sputtering from the hot taps indicates partial air ingress or internal scaling. If the building uses a communal hot water storage system, the freeholder or managing agent must ensure regular maintenance and descaling of tanks in accordance with the manufacturer‚Äôs guidance and Legionella control standards.<br>
<br>
The hot and cold supplies within the flat appear to be distributed via copper pipework running within the kitchen base units and bathroom walls. Connections are compression or soldered joints, which are robust and long-lasting if properly installed. There was no evidence of verdigris, pinholing, or corrosion on the visible copper pipes, indicating that they remain sound. The uPVC waste fittings beneath the kitchen sink and bath are more modern replacements and were dry and adequately jointed.<br>
<br>
The kitchen tap and appliance connections appeared in good condition. There is evidence of supplementary bonding to the copper pipework beneath the sink, which provides electrical safety and is good practice.<br>
<br>
No stopcock was clearly visible within the flat. Locating and testing the internal stopcock is essential to allow the water supply to be isolated in an emergency. The buyer should ask the vendor or managing agent to confirm the exact position of both the flat‚Äôs isolation valve and the main building stopcock.<br>
<br>
The drainage from the bathroom and kitchen discharges into original cast-iron stacks located externally at the rear of the building. These pipes are likely original and now approaching the end of their serviceable life. Cast iron can corrode internally while appearing intact externally, and leaks often develop at joints or where pipes have been painted over. Although the stacks are currently functioning, they should be inspected by a qualified plumber using CCTV survey equipment to assess internal condition and plan for phased replacement with modern uPVC systems.<br>
<br>
There was no visible evidence of lead pipework, which is positive, although concealed sections cannot be fully confirmed without intrusive inspection. Given the age of the building, some original lead may remain in communal risers. Water testing for lead content is recommended if this has not been done as part of routine management company checks.<br>
<br>
No cold-water storage tank was visible within the flat, suggesting that water is supplied directly from the mains or from a communal tank at roof level. Communal storage tanks in buildings of this era should be inspected and cleaned annually under the Building Services Maintenance Schedule. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm that this forms part of the freeholder‚Äôs maintenance obligations.<br>
<br>
The plumbing system overall appears functional but is dated in places. The remaining visible pipework is in serviceable condition, though the presence of older communal steel and cast-iron sections warrants further monitoring. The internal copper and uPVC components should continue to perform adequately for 10+ years, subject to maintenance.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The water supply and plumbing are operational and in adequate condition, though elements of the communal system are ageing. The visible copper and uPVC pipework within the flat is serviceable, but signs of rust in the hot tap water suggest internal corrosion within communal steel pipes or tanks. The managing agent should arrange investigation and replacement of any remaining steel or lead supply lines. The cast-iron waste stacks should be CCTV-inspected and scheduled for renewal as part of planned maintenance. The owner should confirm the location of the internal stopcock and ensure all joints are periodically checked for leaks. Subject to these actions and normal upkeep, the internal plumbing system should remain functional for at least ten years. Failure to address communal corrosion issues could lead to reduced flow, leaks, or contamination of the water supply.</div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">

                    Electricity Supply and Installation
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671568-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The electrical installation within the flat appears to have been modernised, with a new metal consumer unit located within a kitchen base unit. The consumer unit is of 17th Edition specification, incorporating individual RCBO (Residual Current Breaker with Overcurrent) protection on each circuit. The installation label indicates an installation date of approximately August 2021, which means the system is relatively new and should comply with the wiring standards current at that time (BS 7671:2018).<br>
<br>
The consumer unit‚Äôs metal enclosure provides improved fire resistance compared with older plastic models, in line with current IET wiring regulations. The presence of RCBOs offers both overload and earth-fault protection for each circuit, greatly enhancing safety and reducing the risk of electric shock. This installation represents a significant improvement on older systems commonly found in properties of this age.<br>
<br>
The visible wiring within the flat is contained within concealed conduits and PVC-sheathed cables, which are standard for modern installations. No surface-mounted wiring, trailing leads, or outdated fuse boxes were observed. Socket and switch fittings throughout the property are modern white plastic units that appeared securely fixed and free from damage. There is a sufficient number of sockets in most rooms, including the kitchen, where outlets are conveniently placed above the work surface.<br>
<br>
Lighting within the property consists of a combination of wall-mounted fittings and recessed ceiling spotlights. The kitchen ceiling contains recessed downlights, which appeared modern and in working order. It should be confirmed by a qualified electrician that these downlights are fire-rated and fitted with appropriate fire hoods or covers, particularly where ceilings form part of a fire compartment such as between the kitchen and escape route.<br>
<br>
Supplementary bonding to the water pipework was observed beneath the kitchen sink, which is in accordance with electrical safety standards. This provides additional protection against electric shock by ensuring that all metallic components are electrically connected and earthed.<br>
<br>
The hallway smoke alarm is battery-operated and not linked to the main supply. As part of general fire safety upgrades, a mains-powered interlinked smoke and heat alarm system should be installed now in accordance with BS 5839-6:2019 to ensure early detection and compliance with modern safety expectations.<br>
<br>
No evidence of exposed live conductors, broken sockets, or scorch marks was seen, indicating that the visible components are in adequate condition. However, no electrical test certificates were available for review at the time of inspection. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should request an Electrical Installation Condition Report (EICR) confirming that the system was tested and certified upon installation in 2021, and whether this certification remains valid.<br>
<br>
The expected lifespan of a modern electrical installation is typically around 25 to 30 years, provided periodic inspection and testing are carried out every five years by a qualified NICEIC-registered electrician. Annual checks of sockets, light switches, and protective devices should be carried out by the occupant to ensure continued safe operation.<br>
<br>
If any additional electrical alterations are planned‚Äîsuch as the addition of new lighting circuits, extractor fans, or kitchen appliances‚Äîthese must be carried out by a Part P‚Äìregistered electrician and certified under Building Regulations.<br>
<br>
The electrical system provides good functionality and represents a recent upgrade over the original 1930s installation. It should continue to perform safely and reliably for the foreseeable future, with no immediate remedial works required apart from the addition of mains-powered fire detection.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The electrical installation is modern and in adequate condition, with a metal consumer unit installed circa August 2021 providing individual RCBO protection in line with current regulations. The system is expected to remain serviceable for 10+ years, subject to routine testing every five years. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm the existence of a valid EICR and completion certificate for the 2021 installation. A mains-powered, interlinked smoke and heat alarm system should be installed now to upgrade fire safety protection. Failure to maintain periodic inspection could result in undetected faults and increased fire risk.</div>

                <div class="col-xs-12">

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671571-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property is served by a communal or district heating system that provides both space heating and hot water to the individual flats. This arrangement is typical of 1930s apartment blocks that were later upgraded from solid-fuel or gas-fired systems to centralised heating plants. The system supplies hot water through a network of communal pipework, with radiators and towel rails fitted within the flat to distribute heat.<br>
<br>
Within the subject flat, cast iron and tubular steel radiators were observed. These include a traditional cast-iron radiator located near the entry door in the hallway and a chromium-plated tubular towel radiator in the bathroom. The radiators appear to be original or early replacements connected to the communal system and are adequately sized for the spaces they serve. The radiators were free from visible leaks or corrosion, although some minor surface rust was observed at one valve joint in the living area, likely from an older leak. This joint should be checked and resealed by a heating engineer at the next routine service.<br>
<br>
The towel radiator in the bathroom is not securely fixed at the upper brackets and moves slightly when handled. This poses a small but immediate risk of pipe strain or disconnection. The radiator must be refixed now by a qualified heating engineer to prevent future leaks.<br>
<br>
No individual boiler, hot water cylinder, or programmer was observed within the flat, confirming that hot water and heating are delivered communally. Heat is distributed through insulated risers and lateral branches entering each dwelling. Communal systems of this type rely on central plant maintenance by the freeholder or managing agent. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm that the communal heating plant is subject to regular servicing, including flue safety checks, pressure monitoring, and water quality testing.<br>
<br>
The radiators within the flat do not appear to have individual thermostatic radiator valves (TRVs). Without these, the occupants have limited ability to control room temperatures independently. Installation of TRVs by the management company should be recommended during the next maintenance cycle to improve energy efficiency and comfort. TRVs allow for better zoning of heat and compliance with modern efficiency standards under Part L of the Building Regulations.<br>
<br>
The level of warmth provided by district heating systems is generally consistent, but flow rates and timing depend on the central plant‚Äôs control schedule. Residents typically cannot set their own heating times unless local control valves or meters are fitted. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should check whether the flat benefits from a heat meter, as this affects how energy charges are apportioned.<br>
<br>
Hot water pressure was tested at taps in the kitchen and bathroom and was adequate, though minor sputtering was noted at the hot taps, suggesting air or partial blockage in the communal hot water riser. This is a maintenance issue for the managing agent. The presence of rust-coloured water at the hot tap indicates internal corrosion within the steel communal pipework or storage tanks. The management company should arrange for flushing, descaling, and corrosion protection of the system in line with the CIBSE and BSRIA maintenance standards for district heating systems.<br>
<br>
The radiators and pipework are older but functional. The surface paint on the hallway radiator is chipped and should be redecorated with heat-resistant paint during redecoration. The towel radiator, once refixed, should continue to provide adequate service.<br>
<br>
Given the age of the system and materials, the expected remaining lifespan of the communal heating distribution within the flat is approximately ten years, subject to routine servicing and maintenance of the main plant. The radiators themselves can last 30 to 40 years if maintained, while valves and fittings generally require renewal every 10 to 15 years.<br>
<br>
No secondary immersion heater or backup electric heating system was identified. Should the communal heating system fail, temporary portable heating would be required until service is restored. It is therefore important to confirm that the management company operates a maintenance contract with 24-hour call-out cover for system breakdowns.<br>
<br>
The system provides good overall heat distribution when in operation and is in adequate condition for its age. The absence of individual temperature control, however, means the system is less efficient than modern independent installations.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The space heating and hot water are provided by a communal system that is functional but limited in controllability. The radiators are in generally adequate condition, but the towel radiator requires immediate refixing to prevent leaks. The hot water flow is adequate, though rust discolouration indicates corrosion within the communal plant, which should be addressed by the management company. Thermostatic radiator valves should be installed to improve control and efficiency. Subject to these actions and continued maintenance of the central system, the heating and hot water supply should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to refix the bathroom radiator or address communal corrosion could result in leaks, poor heating performance, or damage to finishes.</div>

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671572-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The flat retains the original chimney breasts typical of 1930s construction, though the chimney flues themselves are now redundant and capped. The main fireplace feature is located within the living room, consisting of a cast-concrete surround faced with ceramic tiles. The fireplace is decorative only and no longer in use as a functional heating appliance. The ceramic tiling is aged but intact, and there was no visible cracking, movement, or evidence of damp staining around the chimney breast.<br>
<br>
The chimney breast projects internally through the living and dining areas, with minor hairline cracks visible near the upper corner of the breast in the reception room. These are fine thermal movement cracks within the plaster finish rather than indicators of structural instability. They can be repaired easily with filler and redecorated.<br>
<br>
During inspection, no open or active flue openings were found. The main chimney stacks visible externally are capped, preventing rain ingress and bird entry. This is the correct approach for redundant flues and should continue to prevent water penetration into the upper structure. The capping also reduces heat loss through the chimney, although ventilation of the flue voids remains necessary to prevent condensation or stale air build-up within the sealed stack. It should be confirmed that each redundant flue has been vented at both the top and base using terracotta air bricks or similar passive vents. If these are absent, small ventilated grilles should be fitted to the blocked fireplace openings to maintain airflow.<br>
<br>
No evidence of dampness, efflorescence, or tar staining was observed on the chimney breast surfaces, which suggests that the flues remain dry. However, historic soot residues may still exist within the flue linings, which can hold moisture and produce odours in warm weather. If the flue is to be permanently sealed, a vent should still be retained at the base to mitigate this risk.<br>
<br>
The existing tiled fireplace surround is decorative and stable but may contain old fire cement or mortar materials that could include asbestos, common in pre-1980s fireplaces. These should not be disturbed, drilled, or sanded. If refurbishment is planned, the material must be sampled and tested by a UKAS-accredited asbestos laboratory before work begins.<br>
<br>
Given that the chimney stacks are no longer operational, the flues and chimney breasts are now considered part of the building‚Äôs general structure rather than functional heating components. The condition of the plaster and masonry is generally adequate, and no structural defects were observed.<br>
<br>
If a future owner wished to reinstate a working fireplace or install a gas or solid-fuel appliance, the flue would require full inspection and testing by a HETAS-registered engineer (for solid fuel) or Gas Safe engineer (for gas). A CCTV flue survey would be necessary to check the flue lining, integrity, and ventilation. However, this is not currently recommended, as the building‚Äôs fire strategy and lease conditions are unlikely to permit reinstatement of open-flued appliances.<br>
<br>
The overall expected lifespan of the redundant chimney structure is indefinite, provided ventilation is maintained and the external capping remains intact. Minor decorative cracking and surface wear can be addressed during redecoration.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The fireplaces and chimney breasts are redundant but remain in stable and adequate condition. The tiled fireplace surround in the living room is sound but purely decorative. The chimney stacks are correctly capped, and no signs of dampness or movement were found. It should be confirmed that the disused flues are vented at both the top and base to prevent condensation and must not be sealed without ventilation. Any future alterations should include asbestos testing of old fireplace materials. Subject to these minor checks and normal redecoration, the chimney breasts and flues should remain serviceable indefinitely. Failure to maintain ventilation could lead to condensation within the flues and staining on internal plaster finishes.</div>
