    </div><!-- end ngRepeat: reportItem in vm.reportItems --><div ng-repeat="reportItem in vm.reportItems" class="reportItem ng-scope" id="template-item-14996">
    <a name="1671573" id="report-item-1671573"></a>
    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671573" class="ng-binding">
                    Mechanical, Trickle and Passive Ventilation
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671573-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Ventilation throughout the flat is provided primarily by natural means, with a combination of openable windows, passive wall vents, and background infiltration through the building fabric. There are no mechanical ventilation systems such as extractor fans currently installed in either the kitchen or bathroom, which is below modern standards for a multi-occupancy flat of this type.<br>
<br>
The kitchen contains a passive wall vent located above the worktop area; however, the vent grille has been painted over and is therefore ineffective. This restricts air movement and contributes to stale air and moisture build-up, especially when cooking. The vent grille should be cleared and replaced now with a new adjustable louvred cover to restore functionality. Where feasible, a wall-mounted mechanical extractor fan ducted to the outside should also be installed. This would significantly improve air quality and reduce condensation and surface mould risk.<br>
<br>
In the bathroom, there is a passive offset vent on the rear wall above the shower. Like the kitchen vent, this is also partially blocked by paint and provides little effective extraction. The absence of mechanical extraction in a bathroom is a notable defect, as it allows humid air to linger, leading to peeling paint, localised mould, and potential deterioration of plaster and joinery. A wall-mounted or ceiling-mounted axial extractor fan should be installed now, ducted externally and fitted with an integral humidistat or overrun timer. This will ensure effective removal of moisture and compliance with Building Regulations Approved Document F.<br>
<br>
There is no visible trickle ventilation within the window frames. The Critall steel-framed windows are original and do not incorporate integrated trickle vents. In their absence, background ventilation relies entirely on window opening. However, due to the age of the frames, operation can be difficult, and occupants may be reluctant to open windows during cold weather. Retrofitting discrete trickle vents to the window heads or frames should be considered during any future refurbishment. Alternatively, replacement with double-glazed steel or aluminium units incorporating trickle ventilation would improve air exchange and energy efficiency.<br>
<br>
The general ventilation within the living areas and bedrooms depends on manual window opening. The rooms felt adequately aired at the time of inspection, with no evidence of condensation staining or damp odours, which suggests that natural air movement is reasonable. However, in periods of high humidity or cold weather, insufficient background ventilation could lead to condensation forming on cold surfaces, particularly around the metal window frames and uninsulated external walls.<br>
<br>
There is no evidence of ducted ventilation or mechanical assistance for the communal areas. The stairwells and corridors rely on openable windows and natural airflow. While acceptable for an older building, this arrangement can result in limited air movement on still days. The management company should ensure that all communal vents and windows are kept operable and that any fire safety systems (such as smoke vents) are maintained according to current standards.<br>
<br>
The absence of effective mechanical extraction in both the kitchen and bathroom presents a moderate condensation risk and should be addressed as a matter of priority. The installation of fans in these rooms would bring the ventilation performance up to a more modern standard and reduce the likelihood of internal moisture damage.<br>
<br>
The passive and natural ventilation measures currently in place provide minimal airflow but are inadequate for moisture-prone rooms. Trickle vents or discreet vent grilles should also be considered for installation in the main living areas to ensure continual background air exchange.<br>
<br>
The expected service life of a new mechanical extractor fan installation is around ten years, while passive vents will remain serviceable indefinitely if kept clear and maintained.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The current ventilation provision is limited and below modern standards. The kitchen and bathroom lack mechanical extraction, and existing passive vents are obstructed by paint. This condition allows humidity to accumulate and increases the risk of condensation and mould. A mechanical extractor fan must be installed now in the bathroom and recommended in the kitchen, both vented externally. Trickle vents or unobstructed passive grilles should also be introduced to improve background airflow. Subject to these upgrades and routine cleaning of vents, the ventilation system will perform adequately for at least ten years. Failure to improve ventilation will likely result in recurring condensation, peeling decoration, and possible mould growth, particularly in colder months.</div>

    </div><!-- end ngRepeat: reportItem in vm.reportItems --><div ng-repeat="reportItem in vm.reportItems" class="reportItem ng-scope" id="template-item-14997">
    <a name="1671574" id="report-item-1671574"></a>
    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">
            <div class="col-md-7 col-xs-7">
                <h3 id="report-item-navigation-1671574" class="ng-binding">
                    Drainage: Foul, Surface, and Underground
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] --><gr-rating ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" ratings="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID]" report-item="reportItem" class="ng-scope ng-isolate-scope"><!-- ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false --><nav class="menu rating ng-scope" ng-if="vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] !== false">
    <input type="checkbox" href="#" class="menu-open" name="menu-open" ng-class="{'toggle': vm.optionsOpen}" id="menu-open">
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected === null -->
    <!-- ngIf: vm.currentlySelected !== null --><label class="menu-open-button rating ng-binding ng-scope" ng-if="vm.currentlySelected !== null" ng-style="{'background': vm.currentlySelected['shape-fill'], 'color': vm.currentlySelected['label-colour'] }" for="menu-open" ng-click="vm.toggleOptions()" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

    <a uib-tooltip="No rating" tooltip-append-to-body="true" ng-click="vm.selectOption(null)" class="menu-item rating unselected">
    </a>

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671574-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property is connected to a shared foul and surface water drainage system typical of 1930s purpose-built apartment blocks. The flat discharges waste via internal branch pipework to communal cast-iron soil and waste stacks located externally at the rear of the building. Rainwater from the roof and upper surfaces is conveyed through uPVC guttering and downpipes, which discharge into ground-level gullies also serving the foul system.<br>
<br>
The soil and waste stacks visible at the rear of the property are 100 mm (4 inch) cast iron and appear to be original. Although they were in adequate condition externally, these pipes are approaching the end of their expected service life. Surface corrosion and paint deterioration were noted, particularly at joints and rodding eyes. While no active leaks were seen, corrosion inside older cast-iron stacks can progress unseen, leading to blockages or failure. Internal corrosion also roughens the pipe bore, reducing flow capacity and increasing the likelihood of waste build-up. A CCTV drainage inspection by a qualified plumber is strongly recommended within the next twelve months to assess the internal condition of the cast-iron stacks and underground connections.<br>
<br>
The gullies at the base of the building receive waste from downpipes, kitchen, and bathroom outlets. Several gullies were noted to have upstands in need of repair, with some showing minor cracking and wear. Although they were generally clear of debris, the mortar around the bases was eroded in places, which can allow water to seep into the adjacent structure or soil. These gullies should be re-bedded and resealed by a groundworks or drainage contractor within the next year to maintain proper function and prevent water pooling near the building‚Äôs foundation.<br>
<br>
Surface water drainage from the paths and paved areas around the building is adequate, with gentle falls away from the structure. Minor cracking was seen in the concrete pavement near the rear fire escape, but this is age-related and not currently affecting water flow. However, the area should be monitored to ensure that rainwater continues to drain freely to gullies and does not pond against the plinth or wall base, as this could lead to damp ingress over time.<br>
<br>
The underground drainage system is assumed to comprise clay pipes original to the 1930s construction. These systems typically have long lifespans (70‚Äì100 years) but are prone to joint displacement or root ingress where nearby trees are present. The presence of large trees at the rear of the building increases this risk. It is recommended that the management company commissions a CCTV survey of the below-ground drainage network within the next two years to confirm alignment and identify any cracked or displaced sections requiring repair.<br>
<br>
No evidence of foul odours, leaks, or blocked appliances was noted within the flat, indicating that internal waste traps and falls are functioning properly. The slow bath drainage noted during inspection is likely due to partial obstruction or limited venting rather than a systemic issue. A plumber should clear this waste line and check that the air admittance or stack vent is operating correctly.<br>
<br>
Rainwater from the roof is collected by uPVC gutters and downpipes, which appeared serviceable and correctly connected into the ground gullies. It is assumed that these lead to the same below-ground drainage system as the foul water. Regular clearing of the gutters and gullies should be included in the management company‚Äôs maintenance plan to prevent blockages and surface overflow.<br>
<br>
Given the age of the building, separate systems for surface and foul water may not be present, meaning both discharge into the same combined drain. This is common for the period but can lead to overloading during heavy rainfall. If future maintenance works are undertaken, consideration should be given to introducing separate connections for surface water where feasible, though this would require extensive alteration and would normally fall under the freeholder‚Äôs responsibility.<br>
<br>
The drainage system, as observed, is functional and shows no evidence of immediate failure. However, both the external cast-iron stacks and underground clay pipes are nearing the upper end of their typical service life and should be included in planned replacement programmes within the next decade.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The foul, surface, and underground drainage systems are functioning but ageing. The external cast-iron soil stacks are original and likely corroded internally; a CCTV survey is recommended within twelve months to determine condition and plan for eventual replacement. The rear gullies require localised repair and re-bedding to prevent water seepage. The underground clay drains are likely to remain serviceable for several more years but should be inspected within two years due to nearby tree roots. Subject to these inspections, repairs, and routine clearing of gullies and gutters, the system should remain functional for at least ten years. Failure to investigate or maintain the ageing cast-iron stacks could result in leaks, foul odours, or blockages requiring more costly remedial work later.</div>

                <div class="col-xs-12">

                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->
                </div>
            </div><!-- end ngIf: vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes' -->

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671577-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Moisture readings were taken at accessible locations throughout the flat using a hand-held electronic moisture meter. The readings were generally within acceptable parameters for a property of this age, with no active dampness detected under normal conditions.<br>
<br>
All wall surfaces beneath the windows in the bedrooms, living room, and dining area were tested. The results were low and consistent, indicating dry conditions. The areas under the windows in both bedrooms appeared particularly dry, with no signs of condensation or damp staining. This suggests that the external brickwork and window seals remain effective at preventing water ingress.<br>
<br>
Slightly elevated surface moisture levels were detected to the front elevation brickwork beneath the parapet wall, where frost-damaged bricks were noted externally. This dampness is confined to the outer leaf and not evident internally, but it does indicate that rainwater absorption through weathered bricks and inadequate coping drips may be occurring. This issue should be addressed through external repointing and improved drip detailing on the coping stones to prevent further saturation of the brick face.<br>
<br>
No significant moisture readings were recorded on internal partition walls, chimney breasts, or skirting board junctions. The plaster finishes throughout the flat are dry and sound. Minor condensation risk exists in the kitchen and bathroom, where high humidity was noted due to lack of mechanical extraction. In these areas, the meter registered slightly higher readings at the junction between walls and ceilings, typical of condensation rather than rising or penetrating damp. Installation of extractor fans as previously recommended will help prevent future surface dampness.<br>
<br>
No readings indicated rising damp at the base of walls, which is consistent with the property‚Äôs construction, as all floors are of solid concrete. The absence of timber subfloors eliminates the usual routes for moisture ingress associated with older suspended timber structures.<br>
<br>
A historic water stain was observed on the ceiling in the communal hallway outside the flat, although the area was dry at the time of inspection. This is likely related to a previous leak from service pipework or the roof, now resolved. The stain should be redecorated once confirmed dry by the management company.<br>
<br>
Overall, the moisture condition throughout the flat is good, with no evidence of active dampness or concealed leaks. Isolated higher readings in humid rooms are atmospheric in origin and manageable through improved ventilation.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
High moisture readings were not identified within the flat. Localised elevated readings were confined to humidity-prone areas such as the kitchen and bathroom and are attributable to inadequate ventilation rather than structural dampness. Minor external moisture retention is present in the parapet brickwork due to weathering but has not affected the internal environment. The property is otherwise dry, and the internal plaster finishes are sound. Installing mechanical extraction and repairing external coping drips will mitigate future risk. Failure to improve ventilation could allow condensation-related surface dampness and mould growth to develop over time.</div>

            <!-- ngIf: vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes' --><div class="row ng-scope" ng-if="vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes'">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671578-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Timber elements within the flat are limited mainly to internal joinery, window boards, door frames, skirting boards, and floor finishes. The building is of concrete-framed construction, meaning there are no exposed structural timber joists or roof timbers associated with the subject flat. The visible timbers are therefore secondary fittings and decorative components.<br>
<br>
The window boards beneath the Critall steel-framed windows exhibit localised timber decay caused by prolonged condensation and minor water ingress from the metal frames. Paint finishes on several sills, particularly in the kitchen and bedrooms, are flaking, and some surface softness was noted when lightly probed. This decay is superficial at present but will progress if not repaired. The affected sections should be stripped back, treated with a proprietary wood hardener, filled with a two-part epoxy resin, or spliced with new treated softwood, then repainted with a durable microporous coating. These works should be completed within the next twelve months.<br>
<br>
Timber skirting boards, architraves, and door frames throughout the flat are painted softwood and generally in sound condition. There were no signs of active rot, beetle infestation, or moisture staining at skirting level, and no high moisture readings were recorded at these locations. Minor shrinkage gaps were noted at joints and corners, which are cosmetic and typical of seasonal movement. These can be filled during the next redecoration cycle.<br>
<br>
The internal doors and frames are of hollow-core construction with timber linings and trims. The door frames remain solidly fixed and free from decay. Paint finishes are thick and slightly aged, suggesting multiple layers of historic oil-based paint, which may contain lead. If redecoration is planned, all sanding should be carried out using wet methods to minimise dust exposure.<br>
<br>
In the hallway cupboard and bathroom cupboard, timber shelving and door linings were observed. These timbers were dry with no evidence of fungal growth or active wood-boring insect activity. The bathroom cupboard shelving should, however, be sealed or painted with moisture-resistant paint to prevent future absorption of humidity, as this area experiences elevated moisture levels.<br>
<br>
The timber strip flooring in the living areas and bedrooms is in adequate condition, with slight creaking in the hallway. There is no evidence of damp-related damage, distortion, or decay. The creaking is most likely due to loose fixings over the concrete substrate rather than structural weakness. Re-fixing loose boards will resolve this issue.<br>
<br>
Overall, all visible timberwork is dry, stable, and in serviceable condition. No evidence of active woodworm, wet rot, or dry rot was identified during inspection. Given the nature of the building‚Äôs concrete structure, hidden timber decay is unlikely except in areas subject to prolonged condensation, such as window reveals.<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of all internal timber components is in excess of ten years, provided periodic redecoration and localised repair are undertaken.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
Timber elements within the flat are generally in adequate condition with no evidence of structural decay or infestation. Minor localised decay was noted to the window boards due to condensation, which requires repair and repainting within the next year. All other internal joinery remains dry and stable. No concealed structural timbers are present in this type of concrete-framed property, so the overall risk of timber decay is low. Subject to normal maintenance and repainting every five to seven years, the timberwork will remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to repair decayed window boards or maintain protective paint finishes could allow moisture ingress and more extensive timber deterioration over time.</div>

            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671580-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Your attention is drawn to the fact that the soil type in this district is Soilscape 14: Freely draining very acid sandy and loamy soils. Sandy soils pose a high risk of subsidence as they easily wash away if water flow is caused by defective drainage, gutters, plumbing, etc. <br>
 <br>
Soils are susceptible to shrinkage during periods of extremely dry weather, as the volume of the clay changes in proportion to its moisture content.  <br>
 <br>
The risk of foundation damage increases significantly when trees or shrubs are planted near buildings. As a general policy, no shrubs or trees with high water demand are recommended to be planted close to any buildings. You should be ensured that your building insurance policy includes adequate cover for subsidence and heave damage.</div>

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671581-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">No significant evidence of active or progressive structural movement was identified within the flat or the surrounding external elements of the block at the time of inspection. The building, dating from the 1930s, is of concrete-framed construction with masonry infill panels, a robust form of structure that performs well over time and is generally resistant to the types of subsidence and settlement seen in older loadbearing masonry buildings.<br>
<br>
Internally, all walls appeared plumb and true, with no signs of bulging, distortion, or stepped cracking around door frames or window openings. The minor hairline cracks observed in the living room, particularly around the upper corner of the chimney breast, are thermal or decorative in nature and attributable to normal plaster shrinkage rather than structural movement. These can be filled and redecorated as part of routine maintenance.<br>
<br>
Externally, the brickwork of the elevations appears upright and stable. No bulging, bowing, or differential settlement was apparent. The frost-damaged bricks noted beneath the coping stones on the front parapet wall are the result of weather exposure and inadequate drip detailing rather than movement or structural instability. The concrete frame elements showed no visible cracking or spalling indicative of movement or reinforcement corrosion.<br>
<br>
The small crack recorded in the front concrete step below the entry door was identified as differential settlement between adjoining concrete sections. This is minor, isolated, and cosmetic only, requiring no structural intervention beyond routine repair. Such hairline movement is typical for buildings of this age and does not suggest foundation weakness.<br>
<br>
No distortions were visible around window heads, lintels, or door openings within the flat. All openings operated freely, confirming that no significant structural displacement is affecting the frame or surrounding walls.<br>
<br>
Given the property‚Äôs location, the surrounding soil type, and the presence of mature trees close to the rear elevation, there is a low to moderate long-term risk of minor movement due to soil shrinkage or root activity. However, there is currently no evidence of such effects on the structure. The trees should be monitored by the management company as part of their grounds maintenance to ensure that excessive root spread does not begin to undermine the paved areas or foundations.<br>
<br>
The reinforced concrete frame construction is inherently stable and distributes loads evenly. Unless there is significant water ingress or corrosion of reinforcement (none of which was noted), the likelihood of structural failure is minimal.<br>
<br>
No evidence of recent settlement, lateral displacement, or deflection was seen at ceiling junctions, floors, or walls. Floor levels within the flat are even and firm, with no indication of subsidence or heave.<br>
<br>
Overall, any observed cracking or movement is superficial and consistent with age-related thermal and decorative changes, not structural instability.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
There is no evidence of active structural movement affecting the property. Minor plaster cracks in the living room and localised weathering to parapet brickwork are superficial and not indicative of structural distress. The concrete frame and foundations appear stable, and no action is required beyond normal maintenance. The proximity of large trees at the rear introduces a low long-term risk of ground shrinkage, and these should be periodically monitored by the management company. Subject to routine maintenance and monitoring, the risk of future movement is considered low. Failure to maintain external rainwater goods or monitor tree growth could increase future movement risk due to localised moisture variation in the subsoil.</div>

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671585-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property benefits from communal gardens located at the front of the block, consistent with the design of 1930s residential developments. These areas are shared by all residents and maintained under the building‚Äôs service charge arrangement. The gardens appeared well kept at the time of inspection, with maintained lawns, planted borders, and mature shrubs. There was no evidence of neglect, overgrowth, or poor drainage.<br>
<br>
The communal lawns slope gently away from the building, assisting surface water run-off and reducing the risk of moisture accumulation against the base of the external walls. No signs of waterlogging or ponding were observed, and the ground appeared firm and adequately drained. Regular maintenance of soil levels and grass cutting should continue under the management company‚Äôs maintenance contract.<br>
<br>
Hardstanding areas, including the access paths and driveways surrounding the block, are of asphalt and concrete construction. The surfaces are generally in adequate condition, with some localised cracking in the asphalt noted around the perimeter road and near the rear fire escape. These cracks are caused by tree root pressure from nearby mature trees and are not unusual in older communal areas. They should be monitored annually and re-sealed or resurfaced where necessary to prevent water penetration and further deterioration.<br>
<br>
Several large mature trees are situated close to the rear boundary of the site. These trees contribute to the character of the setting but pose a potential long-term risk of root encroachment into drainage systems or foundations. The management company should ensure that the trees are inspected every two years by a qualified arboriculturist to monitor root spread and canopy health. Pruning or root barrier installation may be required if movement or cracking in adjacent hard surfaces worsens. No immediate remedial action is needed at this stage.<br>
<br>
Communal planting beds and borders appeared tidy, with no visible signs of invasive vegetation such as Japanese Knotweed or giant hogweed. Routine weeding and trimming are sufficient to maintain them. If any invasive species are later identified, the management company must arrange for specialist eradication in accordance with the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.<br>
<br>
The boundary walls and fences around the garden area were not described as defective and are assumed to be part of the freeholder‚Äôs maintenance responsibilities. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should confirm this within the lease documentation, as the leaseholder‚Äôs obligations generally extend only to maintaining internal parts of the flat.<br>
<br>
No private garden areas are included within the demise of the subject flat, and residents share the communal grounds equally. Therefore, any maintenance issues, including tree care, boundary repairs, or resurfacing of communal paths, should be managed collectively by the freeholder or management company under the service charge.<br>
<br>
The overall condition of the gardens and hardstanding is adequate, well maintained, and requires no immediate repair beyond normal cyclical grounds maintenance.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The communal gardens are well maintained and in adequate condition, providing a pleasant setting for the property. Minor cracking in the asphalt paths and the presence of mature trees at the rear should be monitored as part of routine estate management. Tree inspections should be carried out every two years by a qualified arboriculturist to prevent potential root-related damage to drains or paving. Subject to continued management and regular maintenance, the gardens and surrounding areas are expected to remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to manage tree growth or repair cracked hard surfaces could allow water ingress and progressive deterioration of paths and boundaries over time.</div>

    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671586-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The driveway and access road surrounding the block are of asphalt construction laid over a compacted sub-base, typical of 1930s communal residential developments. The surface provides vehicular access to the rear garages and general service access around the perimeter of the building. At the time of inspection, the driveway appeared generally level and functional, allowing safe vehicle and pedestrian use.<br>
<br>
The asphalt surface is aged and exhibits several hairline and localised cracks, particularly near the edges and adjacent to the tree-lined boundary at the rear. These cracks are likely caused by thermal expansion, age-related wear, and minor ground movement from nearby tree roots. The defects are superficial and not currently affecting usability, but if left untreated they will allow water ingress and lead to surface fretting, potholes, and frost damage. Routine patch repairs or localised resurfacing should therefore be carried out within the next two years to maintain the surface integrity.<br>
<br>
The drainage falls along the driveway are adequate, directing rainwater towards existing gullies and away from the building. No significant standing water or ponding was observed. The gullies themselves appear functional but should be kept clear of debris and periodically flushed to ensure they remain free-flowing, particularly during autumn when leaf fall is heaviest.<br>
<br>
The driveway edges and kerb lines appear sound, though some erosion and crumbling were noted at junctions with the concrete pavement near the fire escape. These areas should be re-bedded with fresh asphalt or concrete to prevent water ingress beneath the surface course.<br>
<br>
There was no evidence of oil staining, surface subsidence, or rutting that would suggest heavier structural failure. The underlying sub-base is likely original and appears to remain well compacted. Provided minor cracks are sealed and surface dressing maintained, the current surface should provide a further lifespan of approximately ten years before full resurfacing becomes necessary.<br>
<br>
Given that the driveway forms part of the communal estate, maintenance responsibility will rest with the freeholder or management company. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should confirm that repairs and resurfacing are included within the building‚Äôs service charge provision and that a planned maintenance schedule is in place.<br>
<br>
No safety hazards such as uneven trip edges or open drains were noted, and the driveway remains safe for normal residential use.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The asphalt driveway is functional and in generally adequate condition, with minor cracking and surface wear consistent with age. Localised patch repairs and re-sealing should be undertaken within two years to prevent further deterioration. Regular cleaning of gullies and monitoring of root-related cracking near trees should form part of the management company‚Äôs maintenance routine. Subject to these minor works, the driveway should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to repair early cracks could result in potholing, increased surface water ingress, and more costly resurfacing in the future.</div>

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671588-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The retaining and boundary structures around the property consist primarily of low brick boundary walls and sections of fencing enclosing the communal gardens to the front and rear of the block. These are typical for 1930s residential developments and generally perform both aesthetic and functional roles in defining the communal grounds.<br>
<br>
The front boundary wall is constructed of traditional clay brickwork laid in stretcher bond, capped with concrete coping stones. The wall appeared plumb and stable, with no bulging, rotation, or cracking visible at the time of inspection. The coping stones remain firmly fixed, though the mortar joints show localised weathering consistent with age. Repointing with a lime-based mortar is recommended within the next five years to maintain the integrity of the joints and prevent moisture penetration through the wall head. The wall height is modest and presents no structural hazard.<br>
<br>
At the rear of the block, the boundary is formed by a combination of brick walls and timber fencing panels mounted between concrete posts. The brickwork sections appear stable and adequately bonded. Some minor mortar loss and surface efflorescence were observed near ground level, attributable to rising damp and splash-back from rainfall. These defects are superficial and can be rectified through low-level repointing and cleaning during routine maintenance.<br>
<br>
The timber fencing panels are serviceable but aged. The lower sections of several panels display early signs of rot, where moisture has been absorbed from ground contact. These panels are nearing the end of their serviceable life and should be replaced within the next two years with pressure-treated timber or composite alternatives. Applying a preservative coating every three to five years will help prolong their lifespan. Replacement of the panels should be undertaken by a fencing contractor, ensuring that the posts are set in concrete and the panels raised slightly above ground to prevent water absorption.<br>
<br>
No structural retaining walls were identified supporting significant changes in ground level around the block. The site is generally level, with only gentle falls for drainage. Low plinth and edging walls around planting beds act as minor retainers but showed no cracking or displacement. These are stable and require only routine cleaning and redecoration.<br>
<br>
The boundary structures showed no signs of instability, leaning, or subsidence that would indicate foundation movement. Vegetation growth along the base of the rear walls should, however, be controlled to prevent root action from disrupting mortar joints over time.<br>
<br>
Responsibility for the maintenance of all boundary and retaining walls and fencing will rest with the freeholder or management company, as these are communal estate features. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm this within the lease and service charge documentation.<br>
<br>
The expected remaining lifespan of the brick walls is in excess of ten years, subject to periodic repointing and maintenance of the coping stones. The timber fencing panels have an estimated remaining life of up to five years before replacement becomes necessary.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The retaining and boundary walls and fences are in adequate condition and stable for their age. Localised mortar weathering and minor timber decay were observed but do not currently compromise structural integrity. Repointing of brickwork within five years and replacement of deteriorated fencing panels within two years are recommended. Regular vegetation control and application of timber preservatives will prevent premature decay. Subject to these minor works and normal estate maintenance, the boundary structures should remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to maintain joints or renew decayed fencing could result in localised collapse, loss of boundary definition, or moisture penetration into adjoining areas.</div>

            <div class="row">
                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.templateitem.ActiveResponseCount > 0 --><button ng-if="reportItem.templateitem.ActiveResponseCount &gt; 0" class="btn-default btn predefined-response btn-add-response pull-left ng-scope" ng-click="vm.openModal(reportItem, true)">Add Response</button><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.templateitem.ActiveResponseCount > 0 -->

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671589-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The paths and paved access areas around the block are of concrete and asphalt construction, typical of 1930s communal residential schemes. These provide pedestrian routes to the main entrances and access around the rear fire escape. The surfaces appeared generally even and safe underfoot, with no major trip hazards or significant surface failure visible at the time of inspection.<br>
<br>
The front entrance path comprises in-situ concrete slabs leading from the communal garden to the main doorway. The surface is largely intact, with only minor hairline cracking consistent with age and normal settlement. The joints between slabs remain well aligned, and there is no sign of heaving or differential movement. Regular cleaning and removal of moss or algae growth are advised to prevent slipperiness, particularly in damp weather. Application of a light biocidal wash once or twice a year will help maintain traction.<br>
<br>
To the rear of the property, the access path leading to the fire escape and rear service area is formed of poured concrete, which shows moderate age-related wear. Minor cracking and surface erosion were noted, particularly near the steps and gullies. These cracks are non-structural and appear stable, likely resulting from thermal expansion and contraction rather than subsidence. They should be sealed within the next twelve months using an appropriate resin filler to prevent water ingress and frost damage during winter months.<br>
<br>
The concrete around the base of the rear fire escape steps is similarly worn, with some small spalls and surface chipping evident. This area remains safe to use but would benefit from patch repairs and repainting to maintain durability and appearance. The cracked plinth adjacent to the path is due to old age and localised wear; it poses no safety concern but should be repaired during the next maintenance cycle.<br>
<br>
Drainage falls from the paths are adequate, with surface water directed away from the building and towards existing gullies. No ponding or waterlogging was observed. The gullies themselves, while functional, have some deteriorated upstands and mortar joints that require attention within the next year to maintain watertightness.<br>
<br>
No separate patio areas were noted within the communal grounds, though the concrete paths around the gardens serve the same purpose for access and maintenance. These areas are functional and visually consistent with the age and character of the property.<br>
<br>
The overall condition of the paths is adequate, with wear consistent with their age and use. The expected remaining lifespan of the concrete and asphalt surfaces is approximately ten years, subject to routine maintenance such as cleaning, sealing cracks, and localised resurfacing as required.<br>
<br>
As these are communal access routes, the responsibility for their maintenance and repair will rest with the freeholder or management company. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser must confirm that these works are included in the service charge provisions and that the surfaces are inspected periodically for safety.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The paths and access areas are in adequate condition and serviceable, with only minor cracking and surface wear noted. Localised repairs and joint sealing should be completed within twelve months to prevent water ingress and surface deterioration. Regular cleaning is required to prevent moss growth and maintain slip resistance. Subject to these minor works and normal cyclical maintenance, the paths should remain functional for at least ten years. Failure to carry out crack repairs and cleaning could result in further erosion, frost damage, and an increased risk of slips or trips in wet weather.</div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" --><div ng-if="reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Section Heading&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;RICS Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;Fixed Row Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot; &amp;&amp; reportItem.ItemType !== &quot;GVA Summary Table&quot;" class="ng-scope">

    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671590-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The property includes both front entrance steps and rear external steps forming part of the communal fire escape. These are original features of the 1930s block and constructed primarily of cast concrete with mild steel handrails. Both sets of steps provide adequate access and escape routes but show minor age-related wear that should be addressed during routine maintenance.<br>
<br>
At the front of the block, the main entrance step is formed in pre-cast concrete. A visible crack runs across the step just below the entry door. This crack appears to result from differential settlement between adjoining concrete sections and is superficial in nature rather than structural. The step remains firm and safe underfoot. The joint should be cleaned, sealed, and surface-repaired with a suitable exterior-grade mortar or epoxy resin filler within the next twelve months to prevent water ingress, frost expansion, and further surface deterioration.<br>
<br>
The surface texture of the front step is slightly worn, reducing its slip resistance. Application of a proprietary anti-slip coating or the installation of slip-resistant nosings is recommended to improve safety, especially in wet or icy conditions. The step nosings should also be clearly visible and highlighted where possible to assist residents and visitors.<br>
<br>
At the rear of the block, the external fire escape steps are of cast concrete construction with metal balustrades and handrails. The steps appeared solid and stable, with no signs of structural cracking or spalling. The treads remain even and serviceable, and the concrete surfaces, while aged, retain good load-bearing capacity. Some minor chipping and edge wear were noted, consistent with long-term exposure to weather and use. These can be repaired using a suitable concrete patching compound during the next maintenance cycle.<br>
<br>
The metal handrails and balustrades were securely fixed and free from significant corrosion. However, they should be periodically repainted with a rust-inhibiting metal paint every five years to prevent deterioration. The balustrade openings were observed to be wider than current Building Regulations allow, presenting a potential safety risk for small children. While this is typical of buildings from this era and does not require immediate remedial work, the managing agent should review the need for retrofitted vertical infill bars or mesh guards to reduce the risk of falls through the openings.<br>
<br>
The concrete around the base of the fire escape and steps showed minor cracking and wear, likely due to thermal movement and age. These defects are cosmetic and can be addressed as part of the same patch repair works recommended for the adjoining pathways. Drainage falls at the base of the steps appear adequate, and no pooling or dampness was evident.<br>
<br>
No ramps were present at either entrance, reflecting the original period design. Accessibility could be improved through installation of a removable or low-gradient ramp system at the front entrance if required in the future, subject to freeholder consent and compliance with the Equality Act 2010.<br>
<br>
Both sets of steps are functional and safe for normal use. The concrete structure is sound and has an estimated remaining lifespan in excess of ten years, subject to minor repairs, sealing of cracks, and periodic redecoration of metalwork.<br>
<br>
Responsibility for maintaining these steps rests with the freeholder or management company, as they form part of the communal fabric of the building. The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should confirm that inspection, repair, and painting of the external steps and metalwork are included within the building‚Äôs service charge provisions.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The external steps to the front and rear are in adequate condition, showing only minor surface wear and cracking consistent with age. The front entrance step requires sealing within the next twelve months to prevent moisture ingress, and anti-slip treatment is recommended to improve safety. The rear fire escape steps and balustrades are stable but would benefit from patch repairs and repainting within two years. Balustrade openings should be reviewed for child safety compliance. Subject to these minor maintenance works, the steps are expected to remain serviceable for at least ten years. Failure to carry out repairs or maintain protective coatings could lead to surface deterioration, corrosion of metalwork, and reduced slip resistance.</div>

            <!-- ngIf: vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes' --><div class="row ng-scope" ng-if="vm.templateSettings.TranscriptionTo != 'Notes'">
                <div class="col-xs-12">
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src === undefined -->
                    <!-- ngIf: vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID] !== undefined && vm.audioUrls[reportItem.ReportItemID][0].src !== undefined -->

                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671592-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Significant vegetation was observed primarily around the rear of the building, where several large mature trees are located close to the boundary and near sections of the access road and fire escape. These trees form part of the communal landscape and contribute positively to the setting and privacy of the property, but they also present potential long-term maintenance and structural risks if unmanaged.<br>
<br>
The mature trees, likely plane or sycamore species, are of considerable height and have well-established root systems extending beneath the surrounding hard surfaces. Minor cracking and undulation in the nearby asphalt and concrete paths suggest historic movement caused by root growth. While no immediate structural damage to the building was evident, the proximity of these trees to the rear elevation increases the risk of future root-related issues, including displacement of paving, damage to underground drains, and localised ground shrinkage during dry weather.<br>
<br>
No tree branches were in direct contact with the building at the time of inspection, although the canopies extend over the rear service areas and roofline. Overhanging branches can impede drainage and contribute to blocked gutters if not pruned regularly. Leaves and debris may also encourage surface moss growth and dampness at the base of the walls. Regular pruning and removal of overhanging branches are recommended within the next twelve months and thereafter as part of an ongoing arboricultural maintenance plan.<br>
<br>
There was no evidence of invasive vegetation such as ivy, Japanese Knotweed, or buddleia growing on or against the building fabric, which is positive. However, smaller shrubs and ground vegetation near the walls should be trimmed back to maintain at least 300 mm of clearance between plant growth and masonry surfaces. This spacing helps prevent trapped moisture, allows for adequate airflow around the walls, and reduces the risk of brickwork saturation.<br>
<br>
Tree root systems, while currently stable, represent a moderate long-term risk to underground drainage and paths. The management company should commission an arboricultural inspection by a qualified arboriculturist every two years to assess tree health, root spread, and the potential need for pruning or root management. Root barriers or containment measures may be recommended if significant encroachment towards drainage lines or foundations is detected.<br>
<br>
The trees should not be removed without professional advice, as abrupt removal of mature vegetation can cause localised heave in shrinkable soils if the site is underlain by clay. An arboriculturist will be able to specify controlled reduction methods to balance structural safety with preservation of amenity value.<br>
<br>
In summary, while the vegetation enhances the site‚Äôs appearance, its proximity to the structure introduces minor but manageable maintenance and structural considerations. Proper monitoring and cyclical maintenance will ensure that the vegetation does not adversely affect the building or its surroundings.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
The significant vegetation around the rear of the property consists of mature trees and established planting that are in good condition but require regular professional maintenance. Overhanging branches should be pruned now to prevent debris accumulation in gutters, and root systems should be monitored every two years to avoid future damage to drainage or paving. Vegetation near walls should be trimmed back to maintain airflow and prevent damp retention. Subject to these maintenance measures, the vegetation should not pose a significant risk. Failure to manage tree growth could result in blocked drainage, localised ground movement, or costly structural and paving repairs over time.</div>

    <!-- ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="HIGH PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(226, 46, 19); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="MEDIUM PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(231, 104, 24); color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="LOW PRIORITY" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(77, 174, 27); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">
        
    </a><!-- end ngRepeat: rating in vm.ratings --><a ng-repeat="rating in vm.ratings" uib-tooltip="NOT INSPECTED" tooltip-append-to-body="true" class="menu-item rating red ng-binding ng-scope" ng-style="{'background': rating['shape-fill'], 'color': rating['label-colour'] }" ng-click="vm.selectOption(rating)" style="background: rgb(179, 179, 179); color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">

</gr-rating><!-- end ngIf: vm.ratings[reportItem.TemplateItemID] -->
                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671596-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">Given the property‚Äôs 1930s date of construction, there is a moderate likelihood that deleterious or hazardous materials may be present within certain original or older building components. While no such materials were disturbed during inspection, several elements were noted as potential sources based on their age and appearance.<br>
<br>
The most significant potential concern relates to textured ceiling coatings present in several rooms, including the hallway, master bedroom, and bedroom two. These coatings may pre-date 1985 and could therefore contain asbestos fibres (commonly chrysotile, or white asbestos). Although the coatings appeared intact and undamaged, any drilling, sanding, or removal work could release fibres. A precautionary asbestos sampling and testing survey by a UKAS-accredited laboratory must be undertaken before any ceiling repairs, redecoration, or electrical alterations are carried out. If confirmed to contain asbestos, the coatings can remain in place if left undisturbed but must be managed under an asbestos management plan.<br>
<br>
Additionally, the tiled fireplace surround in the living room and the associated mortar or fire cement used for fixing may also contain asbestos. Asbestos-containing fireproof materials were commonly used in fireplaces and flue linings up to the late 1970s. Although the fireplace is decorative and no longer in use, it should not be drilled or altered without prior sampling and confirmation that no asbestos is present.<br>
<br>
Paint finishes throughout the flat, particularly on timber doors, skirting boards, and window frames, are likely to include old layers of lead-based paint beneath newer coatings. Lead-based paints were standard prior to the mid-1960s and can still be found under later redecorations. These do not present a health risk if encapsulated beneath sound modern paint but can release harmful dust if sanded or stripped. Any preparation works involving these surfaces must use wet-sanding methods or chemical stripping, and waste must be disposed of safely.<br>
<br>
There is no evidence to suggest the presence of high-alumina cement, calcium chloride additives, or other deleterious materials in the building‚Äôs structural elements. The reinforced concrete frame appears stable and unaffected by chemical deterioration such as carbonation or chloride attack.<br>
<br>
No polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), urea formaldehyde foam insulation (UFFI), or pitch-based damp proof courses were noted, and these materials are not typical of this property‚Äôs construction period.<br>
<br>
Although no immediate health hazards were identified, the age and type of construction mean that asbestos and lead remain the primary deleterious material risks. Safe management of these materials relies on confirmation through testing and adherence to HSE guidance (Asbestos Essentials and Control of Lead at Work Regulations 2002).<br>
<br>
The buyer‚Äôs legal adviser should confirm with the managing agent whether an Asbestos Management Survey has been completed for the block, as this is a statutory requirement for communal areas under the Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012. If no such record exists, it must be arranged as a priority.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
Potential deleterious materials within the flat include textured ceiling coatings and historic paint layers that may contain asbestos and lead respectively. These materials should be assumed hazardous until tested and confirmed otherwise. Sampling by a UKAS-accredited asbestos laboratory must be carried out before any disturbance or refurbishment works. The materials are currently intact and pose no immediate risk if left undisturbed. The buyer should ensure that an Asbestos Management Survey exists for the building and maintain awareness of safe work procedures. Failure to confirm and manage potential asbestos or lead content before undertaking works could result in health hazards, legal liability, and costly remediation requirements.</div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671597-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">JAPANESE KNOTWEED<br>
No Japanese knotweed was identified at the time of the survey. However, it would be best to commission a Japanese knotweed specialist to thoroughly inspect the grounds and surrounding areas within at least a 10-metre radius. <br>
  <br>
Japanese Knotweed is a hardy bamboo-like perennial plant that grows quickly and strongly. It spreads through its underground rhizomes or roots, and thick clumps or stands can quickly grow to over two metres. It was introduced into the United Kingdom in the mid-19th Century and was initially popular with landscapers because it grew quickly and formed dense screens. However, it soon became a problem because of its ability to out-compete indigenous flora and their associated fauna. <br>
  <br>
For further information, you may wish to check out the RICS: <br>
<br>
http://www.ricsfirms.com/residential/maintenance/exterior/how-to-deal-japanese-knotweed/</div>
