                </h3>

            </div>
            <div class="col-md-1 col-xs-1 text-right">

                <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" && vm.selectedReportItemID === reportItem.ReportItemID -->
            </div>
        </div><!-- end ngIf: reportItem.ItemType !== "Section Heading" && reportItem.ItemType !== "RICS Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "Fixed Row Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" && reportItem.ItemType !== "GVA Summary Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Fixed Row Table" -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Section Heading" -->
    </div>

    <div class="row">
        <!-- MULTIPLE TEXT -->
        <!-- ngIf: reportItem.ItemType === "Multiple Text" --><div class="col-md-8 item-value ng-scope" ng-if="reportItem.ItemType === &quot;Multiple Text&quot;">
            <div gr-inline-picklist="" gr-token="" contenteditable="true" data-item-id="1671598-item" class="report-item-value ng-pristine ng-untouched ng-valid ng-not-empty" filternl="true" strippaste="true" striphtml="true" ng-model="reportItem.ItemValue" ng-focus="vm.previousValue(reportItem)" ng-blur="vm.updateItemValue(reportItem)">The flat is situated within a 1930s purpose-built block of flats, a type of construction that generally provides good separation between dwellings due to its solid reinforced concrete frame and concrete floor slabs. This construction offers better sound insulation than lightweight timber structures, but some degree of airborne and impact noise transmission between adjoining flats is still inevitable, particularly where internal finishes have been altered or hard flooring has been installed.<br>
<br>
At the time of inspection, no excessive noise disturbance was noted from neighbouring flats or from the surrounding environment. However, given the communal nature of the building, occasional sound transfer from above, below, or adjacent flats should be expected, particularly from televisions, music, or footfall. The installation of timber or laminate flooring, such as that present in the hallway and living areas, can amplify impact noise. Should noise become intrusive, the leaseholder may consider fitting high-density acoustic underlay or reinstating carpet finishes to reduce transfer. The freeholder‚Äôs consent may be required for such alterations under the lease terms.<br>
<br>
The property is located in a typical residential area, and during inspection there were no unusual external noise sources noted. A police station and a local school are situated within the wider vicinity. These may occasionally contribute to external noise levels during peak hours‚Äîschool start and finish times, or emergency vehicle sirens‚Äîbut such occurrences are intermittent and not considered excessive for an urban setting. The area is otherwise residential in character and provides a reasonable standard of acoustic amenity.<br>
<br>
No evidence of rodent droppings or pest activity was identified within the flat or the communal areas during inspection. The kitchen units and storage cupboards were clear, and no gnawing or droppings were seen around service penetrations or waste pipes. A mouse bait station was noted next to the ground floor fire extinguisher in the communal hallway, suggesting that a preventative pest control regime is already in place under the management company‚Äôs responsibility. This is good practice and should continue with regular monitoring to ensure early intervention if any pest activity recurs.<br>
<br>
No unusual odours or signs of insect infestation were detected. Ventilation within the flat was adequate for its current use, and there was no evidence of mould or biological growth associated with poor hygiene or infestation.<br>
<br>
The general environment around the property is consistent with urban living and poses no specific nuisance or environmental health concerns. Regular cleaning and maintenance of the communal areas will help maintain hygiene and discourage pests.<br>
<br>
SURVEYOR‚ÄôS OVERALL OPINION<br>
<br>
Environmental conditions around and within the property are acceptable. The concrete-framed structure provides reasonable noise separation, although some transmission between flats is to be expected. External noise from the nearby school and police station may be heard intermittently but is typical for an urban location and not considered intrusive. No evidence of rodents or pests was found within the flat. The existing pest prevention measures in the communal areas should continue as part of normal management. Subject to continued good housekeeping and maintenance, no significant environmental risks are anticipated. Failure to maintain communal cleaning or pest control routines could increase the risk of infestation or minor nuisance in the future.</div>
